title: Acoelorrhaphe
comments: This is a very typical look for a mature plant of this species.

children.title: wrightii
children.comments: This species grows straight up in habitat, but in cultivation, at least in California, the stems lean slightly away from each other as they get older.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This is a very typical look for a mature plant of this species.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This species grows straight up in habitat, but in cultivation, at least in California, the stems lean slightly away from each other as they get older.

children.title: A pair
children.comments: When the cultivated plants get old, if they are not supported by more of its kind like in habitat, the stems can start to lean away from the center more and more. These are nine years older than in the previous picture.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: New stems can be removed to form an elegant group, opposed to a massive clump.

children.title: Young
children.comments: This species is very cold tolerant. Some have survived 15F, others can be damaged at 19F.

children.title: Adalescent
children.comments: This plant, in a cold pocket of Northern California's Bay Area, was not damaged by about 18F some months before this picture was taken.

children.title: In Hawaii
children.comments: Native to Florida where they live in high humidity, they naturally thrive in the subtropics.

children.title: In the desert
children.comments: They also grow well in the desert, if given enough water. The crowns are not as lush, with less green leaves, especially compared to those grown in the humid sub-tropics.

children.title: Partially trimmed
children.comments: The leaves, leaf bases and old inflorescences do not fall off on their own, but need to be manually trimmed if you want to see the stems.

children.title: With Washingtonia
children.comments: In several locations, a Washingtonia robusta has been found growing in Acoelorrhaphe clumps, presumably because a small Washingtonia has some resemblance with Acoelorrhaphe and can be overlooked until large.

children.title: Group
children.comments: This is a nice grouping of the species. They would also make affective large screens, especially untrimmed.

children.title: In shade
children.comments: Acoelorrhaphe will grow with some shade, but that will make them slower. Heat and extra water make them grow faster.

children.title: Very wide
children.comments: These old clumps have stems leaning so far away from the center that some are dropping down.

children.title: Twisted stems
children.comments: After growing sideways or dropping down, the stems come back up, forming twists and curves.

children.title: Twisted stems
children.comments: The twists and curves can be very decorative.

children.title: Old stems
children.comments: Each plant has multiple stems that are very narrow.

children.title: Trunks
children.comments: The stems look larger than they are because of the persistant leaf bases surrounded by a thick layer of fiber.

children.title: Young stem
children.comments: Younger parts of the stems are thicker with fiber and the leaf bases still have golden color in them.

children.title: Decorated stems
children.comments: The persistent leaf bases and fiber makes a good base for attaching air plants.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: Although older plants appear lush with many leaves, each stem tends to have only a few green leaves.

children.title: Crowns
children.comments: This older plant also has small crowns with few leaves.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: This younger stem has many leaves in one crown. Note also that these leaves are full round, not have circles, and rather flat.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: The trunk's fiber starts out as ligules at the top of the trunk.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: The petioles, with their golden yellow edges and gold to brown thorns, look similar to Washingtonia petioles.

children.title: Leaves
children.comments: The underside of the leaves have a slightly silvery appearance from small scales, making that side paler than the top side, shown behind this one.

children.title: Variegated
children.comments: It is rare, but occasionally variegated forms can be found.

children.title: Leaf upper side
children.comments: Notice how deeply bifid the leaflets tips are split.

children.title: Leaf upper side
children.comments: The leaf blades are divided between the leaflets about half way down.

children.title: Leaf underside
children.comments: This leaf forms a half circle, and is not flat.

children.title: Hastula upper side
children.comments: The top side hastulas can be irregularly lobed.

children.title: Hastula underside
children.comments: With only a short costa rib extending up the center of the leaf, these are considered as palmate leaves. The hastula on the underside is only a ridge between the costa and the leaf blade.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: The inflorescence is slender and branched to four orders.

children.title: Unripe fruit
children.comments: The fruit is quite small.

children.title: Ripe fruit
children.comments: The fruit turns bluish black when ripe.

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: Illustrated in 1898 as Serenoa aborescens, the name Acoelorrhaphe wrightii was officially given in 1899.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: Illustration published in 1855, even though it was not officially named Acoelorrhaphe wrightii until 1907.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Heart
children.comments: The leaf-bases are exceptionally good looking.  The blue or green of the leaf color is covered with white wax, plus various degrees of pink, orange, brown, and black markings.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: The edge of the petioles have orange-brown spots of fuzzy scale on a white waxy coating. They are especially concentrated around the wings, the thin flanges on the edge of where the petiole and leaf-base comes together.
children.location: Gary and Lynette Wood's South Coast Palms

children.title: Heart
children.comments: The coloring on the leaf-bases varies between different plants. This young plant is red under the white wax and has light fuzz.

children.title: New growth
children.comments: Newer leaves have fuzzy edges on the joined segments.

children.title: Hastula upper side
children.comments: The hastula is usually quite lop-sided.

children.title: Hastula underside
children.comments: Bismarckia have a short, but distinguishable costa ( the pointed end of the petiole that extends into the leaf blade).

children.title: berlandieri
children.comments: This form was an accepted species, but is now listed on Kew as a synonym of B. dulcis.  It matures into a smaller tree than the regular B. dulcis.

children.title: Profile 2014
children.comments: This form was an accepted species, but is now listed on Kew as a synonym of B. dulcis.  It matures into a smaller tree than the regular B. dulcis.

children.title: Profile 2010
children.comments: This picture was taken four years before the previous picture of the same tree.

children.title: Profile 2003
children.comments: This picture was taken seven years before the previous picture, and eleven years before the first picture of the same tree. It is not fast growing.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: The leaves are pale green to blue gray.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: Like B. dulcis, B. berlandieri can be single, or have multiple stems.

children.title: Juvenile
children.comments: Six years earlier, than the previous photo, shows the pups just emerging.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The crowns are usually full and round, but have an open appearance because of the long petioles.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: Brahea have unsplit leaf-bases for quite a way down the stem, but they eventually fall off to make a clean trunk on the lower part of older trees. None of these have reached that stage yet, even though some, like this one, are decades old.

children.title: Leaf bases with fabric
children.comments: The bottom of the leaf bases are very fibrous, leaving the trimmed petioles sticking out of a mass of fiber, which can look like threads or like sheets of loosely woven fabric.

children.title: Leaf bases with fibers
children.comments: This one is showing coarse fibers along the edges of the leaf-bases.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: This one has brown fiber connecting the thorns of the newer petioles.

children.title: Ligules
children.comments: This one is cleaner, with no brown fiber on the thorns.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: They have well developed thorns along a yellow band on the edges of the petioles.

children.title: Petiole hair
children.comments: The newer petioles often have brown fiber on the upper side, that falls away with age.

children.title: Leaf upper side
children.comments: On this tree, the leaf blades are split to one third to one half the leaflet's length, but they can be deeper; it is variable.

children.title: Leaf under side
children.comments: The underside of the leaves have more glaucous white than the upper sides.

children.title: Leaf under side
children.comments: This one, like many other Brahea species, has a moderate amount of fiber hanging from the beginning of the leaflet splits.

children.title: Leaf side view
children.comments: This view shows a mild costapalmate shape to the leaf blade, and a bowl shape around the hastula.

children.title: Hastula
children.comments: Their  hastulas are not large, and they get even smaller as they turn brown and slowly brake off when the leaf gets older.

children.title: Leaf tips
children.comments: The leaflets are split for a moderate length. This picture shows the color difference between the upper side and under side of the same leaf.

children.title: Heart with inflorescence
children.comments: The inflorescence stalks emerge from between the lower leaves.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: The inflorescence is the length of, or slightly longer than the leaves.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: The inflorescence has multiple branches that are covered with cream colored tomentum (fuzz), and the flower buds can be obscured by the fuzz.

children.title: elegans
children.comments: Most B. elegans have retained leaf bases on the trunk and have inflorescences shorter than the leaves. This small, well-formed tree has long inflorescences and a smooth trunk, but we do not know if that was manually done.

children.title: Profile 2014
children.comments: Brahea elegans was a valid species; now, it is mostly considered a variety of B. aculeata or a cross of that and B. brandegeei, but Kew, the Plant List and Don Hodel all have it as a form of B. armata (it is botanically closer to that species). This one could have a slight resemblance to B. clara, and a few un-pictured specimens really look like B. clara, but none look at all like B. armata.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Profile 2004
children.comments: This picture was taken ten years earlier than the same tree in the previous picture, showing a slow rate of growth.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Flowering profile 2013
children.comments: Most B. elegans have retained leaf bases on the trunk and have inflorescences shorter than the leaves. This small, well-formed tree has long inflorescences and a smooth trunk, but we do not know if that was manually done.

children.title: Flowering profile 2005
children.comments: This picture was taken eight years earlier than the same tree in the previous picture. The leaves are not as fine and deeply split as most B. elegans. At that time, it was named Brahea aculeata 'elegans', presumably from when B. elegans was considered a form of B. aculeata.

children.title: Unusual form
children.comments: An extremely variable species, this one has coarse, moderately split leaves, but like the ones with fine leaves, this one also has the costapalmate curve.

children.title: Cold tolerant
children.comments: This is an old specimen that has seen temperatures in the high teens F.

children.title: Typical form 2016
children.comments: This specimen is typical of the fine leafed form, thin leaves both in texture and width, short narrow trunk covered with leaf bases and short inflorescences.

children.title: Profile 2006
children.comments: This picture was taken ten years earlier than the same tree in the previous picture, showing a slow rate of growth, but not exceedingly so.

children.title: Very slow
children.comments: This one is still labeled by its old name, Erythea elegans, which was officially named from a cultivated plant in California in 1908, and then in 1975 all Erythea were merged into Brahea, including this one. It has only recently become unaccepted by botanists.
children.location: Dr. Marty and Cheri Darian's hilltop home

children.title: Glaucous leaves
children.comments: The tree in Los Angeles that B. elegans was described from had glaucous gray leaves. This one exhibits some of that gray color.

children.title: Juvenile
children.comments: Even at a young age, you can tell that this 5-gallon plant will be short with fine, deeply split leaflets.

children.title: Tall form
children.comments: The tallest palm is about 35' tall with a 27' trunk. Looking at the tall slender trunks and thin leaves, you can see why there has been speculation that B. elegans is related to B. brandegeei.

children.title: Tall form
children.comments: This location has very different forms of B. elegans, compared with others in California. Even taking into account that they are much older than most others, these trunks are taller and cleaner than anywhere else, and the leaves are not split deeply at all.
children.copyright: and retouched to make look like old postcard by Chris Stevens © 2010

children.title: Tall trunk
children.comments: This (in the center right) is one of the tallest of the normal forms with retained leaf bases. The picture was taken when it was 45 years old. It is not much shorter than the B. armata on the left, but much more narrow.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: This one is shorter and more typical for its age. The tag still calls it Erythea elegans, so it was probably planted in the 1970's.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Tall clean trunks
children.comments: Many B. elegans in habitat, especially in the northern part of their range in Sonora, are 40 to 65 feet tall and look a lot like B. brandegeei. One of the few things that all B. elegans have in common is a relatively narrow trunk.

children.title: Crown with fruit
children.comments: One of the few things the different forms of B. elegans all have in common is the size of the fruit. They are round and small, two-thirds of an inch across (like B. brandegeei), to three-fourth of an inch across (like B. armata). That is definitely smaller than B. aculeata's nearly one inch across.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The crown on this tall form with coarser slivery leaves is more spherical than on the one in the previous picture.

children.title: Heart on tall form
children.comments: The heart and petioles are also very different at this location on its tall forms. The petioles have more tomentum and smaller thorns, while the heart has more and larger ligules (not shown here).

children.title: Heart
children.comments: The heart on the shorter forms do not have noticeable ligules, only the typical fiber between the leaf bases.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: The petioles have sharp thorns that vary between a moderate size, like this one, and very small.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: This one has coarser leaves (stiffer and less split) than most B. elegans, but like the ones with fine leaves, this one also has the costapalmate curve. In this picture you can also see the conspicuous ligules that are absent in most short and fine forms.

children.title: Coarse leaf top side
children.comments: With the same coarser leaves, this tree also has the ligules and is growing faster with a wider trunk.

children.title: Fine leaf top side
children.comments: This deeply split, fine leaved specimen is staying short for an extremely long time.
children.location: Dr. Marty and Cheri Darian's hilltop home

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: The bottom side is usually the same light green as the top side, or slightly lighter.

children.title: Leaf tips
children.comments: The deeply split, fine leaf type also has very deeply split leaflet tips, sometime more than half the length of the leaf blade, which is very unusual in Braheas, and most other palms.

children.title: Costa
children.comments: This form has a long, strong costa for a Brahea (especially when compared with B. aculeata or B. brandegeei), with no hastula around it (like B. brandegeei has). The leaf blade is attached lower down the petiole on one side than the other.

children.title: Leaf fibers
children.comments: While it is not uncommon for Brahea species to have fiber hanging from the beginning of the leaflet splits, this species, especially the deeply split kind, have more than is usual.

children.title: Inflorescence on tall
children.comments: This location has very different forms of B. elegans. They have short inflorescences with lots of branches.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: This inflorescence on this one is also short, but it is not so clustered with many branches.

children.title: Fruit
children.comments: This one has very long inflorescences with unripe fruit.

children.title: Habitat map
children.comments: The small B. aculeata range, and the three groups of B. elegans, with circles marking exact sightings, are from the article, 'The Palms (Arecaceae) of Sonora, Mexico' by Richard S. Feger and Elaine Joyal, printed in 1999. Note that there are sightings of A. elegans around Nuri (marked with a google map pin). The range for A. armata, B. brandegeei and the large gray line for B. aculeata's range are approximations from Andrew Henderson's 'Field Guide to the Palms of the Americas', 1995.
children.copyright: and assembled by Chris Stevens © 2016, map from google.com (Map data ©2016 Google, INEGI)

children.title: pimo
children.comments: The bottom of new leaves and the petioles are covered with fuzz.

children.title: Profile in 2013
children.comments: This and the next two pictures are of the same palm, each taken three years apart. That is a fair amount of growth for a very slow species.

children.title: Profile

children.title: Profile

children.title: Profile
children.comments: Palm and proud owner, Dennis Willoughby.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: The leaves start exhibiting their droopy characteristics when they get older and larger.

children.title: Profile

children.title: Juvenile palm in 2005
children.comments: This is the same tree, photographed 4 years earlier, as the next picture. It is a very slow grower.
children.location: JD Andersen Nursery- Jerry, Cindy or Dan Andersen

children.title: Profile in 2009
children.comments: This is about how most of these will look for many years after reaching the stage of having mature leaves.
children.location: JD Andersen Nursery- Jerry, Cindy or Dan Andersen

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: Brahea pimo have retained leaf bases for several feet.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: They often have a curve to the bottom of the trunk.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: The base is much wider than the growing tip on shorter trunks, forming a distinct triangular shape.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: Their retained leaf bases are covered with burlap-looking fiber.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: Their retained leaves are usually not split until they are getting ready to fall off.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The Rossten's tree is one of the more mature specimens in California.

children.title: Inner crown
children.comments: The petioles and parts of the leaves are covered with beige tomentum (fuzz), more than on other species of Brahea.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: Some specimens have petioles totally covered in thick fuzz.

children.title: Leaf bases
children.comments: The leaf bases have fibers growing out of them, especially their edges, that wrap around the other leaf bases.

children.title: New spear detail
children.comments: Note the short costa going up the center of the new leaf.

children.title: New spear
children.comments: The new spear is also covered with beige fuzz.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: The bottom of new leaves and the petioles are covered with fuzz.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: Even the small thorns on the newer leaves have fuzzy edges.

children.title: Petiole lower surface
children.comments: The leave's petioles have fuzz throughout their green lives.

children.title: Petiole top side
children.comments: The thorns are not evenly spaced.

children.title: Petiole detail
children.comments: Some thorns are angled towards the center of the tree (like on the previous picture) and other thorns point towards the leaf blade. They seem to go in both directions on this petiole.

children.title: Petiole thorns
children.comments: Close-up of the tomentum (fuzz) on the lower surface of the petiole.

children.title: Leaf upper side
children.comments: The leaves form a nice circle.
children.location: JD Andersen Nursery- Jerry, Cindy or Dan Andersen

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: The leaves are usually only mildly indented in the center (cupped upwards, not totally flat).

children.title: Descending leaves
children.comments: The leaflets can form a 360 degree circle, or less, down to about 270 degrees like the leaf on the far right.

children.title: Leaf detail
children.comments: The leaf blade top sides also have fuzz along the segment seams.

children.title: Leaf upper side
children.comments: The leaflets are split to about three quarters of their length.

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: The leaf tips are bifid for a short distance.

children.title: Leaf detail
children.comments: Just opening leaves have far more fuzz on the lower sides.

children.title: Hastula
children.comments: Tomentum is prominent on younger leaves.

children.title: Hastula upper side
children.comments: As the leaves age, the fuzz wears off. Note the very slight costapalmate effect briefly going up the center of the leaf blade.

children.title: Hastula upper side
children.comments: The hastula is taller on some leaves.

children.title: New leaf lowerside
children.comments: Under side of the hastula is covered with fuzz.

children.title: Leaf underside
children.comments: The fuzz on the lower surface of the leaves lasts the longest along the center fold of the segments.

children.title: Costa
children.comments: Note the short costa up the center of the leaf blade.

children.title: salvadorensis
children.comments: Chris Stevens gives scale to this large leafed Brahea.

children.title: Profile in 2003
children.comments: These first four pictures are of the same palm, each taken several years apart to show growth rate.

children.title: Profile in 2010
children.comments: Chris Stevens gives scale to this large leafed Brahea.

children.title: Older specimen
children.comments: A second, older, specimen of B. salvadorensis, at the Huntington, has much shorter petioles and leaves. This could be from getting more light.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The crown on the older specimen at the Huntington is more compact.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The crown on the younger of the two at the Huntington has long petioles and huge leaves.

children.title: Young specimen
children.comments: One of the few B. salvadorensis growing in a private garden in Southern California.

children.title: Mature trunk
children.comments: The second, older, specimen of B. salvadorensis, at the Huntington, has a taller trunk and the leaf bases are starting to fall away.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: This, and all the following pictures, is of the slightly younger of the two at the Huntington.

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: The tufts of fibers between fused segments on the bottom side of the leaf blades are more prominent closer to the petiole and along the center.

children.title: Hastula underside
children.comments: The tufts of fibers between fused segments on the bottom side of the leaf blades are more prominent closer to the petiole and along the center.

children.title: Leaf underside detail
children.comments: B. salvadorensis have small tufts of fibers between fused segments on the bottom side of the leaf blades.

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: Butia bonnetii was a valid accepted name in the early 1900's, until it was merged into B. capitata along with odorata. However, Cocos australis is considered to be a synonym of Syagrus romanzoffiana.

children.title: capitata--after split
children.comments: Butia capitata when known as Cocos capitata (1839). This is the original capitata, not the one now called B. odorata.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: Butia capitata when known as Cocos capitata (1839). This is the original capitata, not the one now called B. odorata.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: Butia capitata when known as Cocos leiospatha or C. leiospatha var. angustifolia in 1881. This is not the B. capitata grown in California, which is now named B. odorata. Note how different these long fruits are from the rounded fruits of the commonly cultivated form now called B. odorata.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: "A." (on the upper left) is Cocos stolonifera, a synonym of Butia stolonifera (listed as accepted by Kew and "The World Checklist of Palms"). "B." (center pic) is Butia capitata when known as Cocos leiospatha.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: The commonly cultivated jelly palm was called Cocos odorata at the time of this illustration, after its official naming in 1891. Cocos odorata was then lumped into Butia capitata, but is now back to Butia odorata, although it is still commonly called or labeled Butia capitata.

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: The Butia capitata that is now named Butia odorata was named Cocos odorata in 1891 and Butia capitata var. odorata in 1916. The seeds and fruit in this illustration of Cocos odorata clearly shows that it is the same species which is now officially named Butia odorata.

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: Cocos wildmaniana and Cocos arenicola, illustrated in 1903, have both been lumped into Butia paraguayensis. C. arenicola was officially renamed to Butia arenicola and C. wildmaniana to Butia wildmaniana in 1930.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: Illustrated as Cocos yatay in 1881. It was named that in 1844 and was changed to Butia yatay in 1916.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: urens (real)
children.comments: The real Caryota urens looks like a small version of a cross between a gigas type (C. obtusa) and the widely cultivated C. maxima that is incorrectly called C. urens.

children.title: Trunks
children.comments: Sketches of the inhabitants, animal life and vegetation in the lowlands and high mountains of Ceylon, 1867. C. urens is the only Caryota from Ceylon.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: Published in 1829. The inflorescences on the real C. urens are up to three feet long, much shorter and tightly packed, so squatter looking than on what is known in California cultivation as C. urens (but is really C. maxima).
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Profile
children.comments: The real Caryota urens looks like a small version of a cross between a gigas type (C. obtusa) and the widely cultivated C. maxima that is incorrectly called C. urens.

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: Published in 1857.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The real C. urens' leaves have less vertical space between each leaf, and have less primary leaflets per side (20, opposed to 27) and it has shorter, squatter infructescence, than the cultivated palm known as C. urens (C. maxima).
children.copyright: Atamara in 2007, original downloaded from Wikipedia.

children.title: Leaves
children.comments: This species' leaves are less droopy, with more jagged margins and elongated tips, than the cultivated palm known as C. urens (C. maxima).
children.copyright: Atamara in 2007, original downloaded from Wikipedia.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: Illustrated in 1678, many years before it was officially named in 1753 (the same year Caryota genus got its name; C. urens was the only species at that time). Schunda-pana is a synonym of Caryota.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org
