children.title: radicalis
children.comments: The leaves can be green to dark muted green. This dark slightly bluish gray tone is only on the stemless forms.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This is the most cold-hardy Chamaedorea. It tolerated the upper teens (F) in this garden only a few years earlier than this picture.

children.title: From above
children.comments: This species tolerates sun, shade, cold,  some drought and stays short; it is very useful for many difficult situations.

children.title: Group planting
children.comments: They look very good in mass plantings and can be used as a large groundcover.

children.title: Medium green
children.comments: The leaves are denser (leaflets close together) and the petioles are shorter when grown in the shade.

children.title: Deep green
children.comments: The leaves can be green to dark muted green. This dark slightly bluish gray tone is only on the stemless forms.

children.title: Shade grown
children.comments: When grown in the shade, the leaflets are further apart and the petioles are longer. (These were repositioned into the sun just recently.)

children.title: New seedling
children.comments: Chamaedorea seedlings always start with two leaflets.

children.title: Seedling
children.comments: Like almost all palms, they are much slower when seedlings. This one is about 4 years old and just starting to get divided leaves.

children.title: 2 years later
children.comments: Two years after the previous picture shows some growth, but it will be a few more years before it reaches its adult size.

children.title: Heel
children.comments: C. radicalis has a saxophone root with a heel that comes up out of the soil.

children.title: Trunkless
children.comments: This very old specimen has no trunk even though it has been in the ground for many decades.

children.title: Trunks
children.comments: The leaf bases would form crownshafts if they had trunks. These are showing some of their crownshafts because they are root bound in their pots and forced to grow upwards.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: The petioles are quite round, except for a curved indent along the top side.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: The leaves are about the same color on the top and bottom sides.

children.title: Rachis bottom side
children.comments: The bottom side of the rachis is round.

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: The leaflets on this thin leafed specimen curve slightly downwards.

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: This leaf is typical of the form: wide leaflets, spaced closely together, with a thick, leathery, ribbed texture.

children.title: Bottom leaflets
children.comments: The bottom one to five leaflets often veer downwards at an angle to the rest of the leaflets.

children.title: Leaf tip
children.comments: The tip of all Chamaedorea leaves end in two leaflets.

children.title: Rachis top side
children.comments: The rachis top side has a ridge down the center.

children.title: Leaflets
children.comments: The leaflets are thick, ridged and leathery.

children.title: Fruit
children.comments: The females readily fruit and form clusters of ornamental orange to red berries.

children.title: Male inflorescense
children.comments: The male flowers can continually release pollen for many months.

children.title: radicalis arborescens
children.comments: They grow well in sun or shade, have a good wind tolerance, and transplant fairly easily.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This species is very easy to grow, especially handy where the shade situation is likely to change over the years.

children.title: Single profile
children.comments: They grow well in sun or shade, have a good wind tolerance, and transplant fairly easily.

children.title: Parents to many
children.comments: The two trees shown at this nursery are probably the source of many of this form in California.
children.location: Gary and Lynette Wood's South Coast Palms

children.title: Moderately fast
children.comments: They can grow tall at a moderately fast rate, and then slow down to not get too tall. This one is about 15 years old.

children.title: Very useful
children.comments: This is a very useful tree if you want something medium tall and narrow, and once it grows above the roof, out of the shade and into the sun, it will still be happy.

children.title: Short
children.comments: These are short, so one would assume them to be the regular C. radicalis, but since they are located under a tree-form, and have the brighter green leaves, they are probably C. radicalis arborescens.

children.title: Group planting
children.comments: These palms always grow as singles, but look best when planted in groups.

children.title: Potted
children.comments: They are easy to keep in a pot for many years, so would make good house plants if given enough light.

children.title: Short nodes
children.comments: This one has very short nodes for this species, which would indicate it was slow growing and is quite old.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: The nodes in the trunk can be long, like in the bottom half of this trunk, or shorter, as in the top part.

children.title: Trunks
children.comments: The trunks can be medium green to dark green with a coating of white glaucous.

children.title: Cleaned crownshaft
children.comments: The yellow parts shown here as well as in the previous picture are from recent exposure when the dead leaf sheaths were taken off.

children.title: Crownshaft
children.comments: The crownshafts are narrow, but usually distinct when not obscured by old leaf sheaths.

children.title: Uncleaned crownshaft
children.comments: When not cleaned for a while, the trunk and crownshaft will be covered with old brown leaf bases. These should be carefully removed to help combat the pests that like to live under them, except in very cold areas where they help insulate.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The crowns are sparse, with only 5 to 6 leaves.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: The petioles and crownshaft have more glaucous white coating than the leaves, making them look slightly turquoise. That is not a ligule at the base of the petiole, but a leaf from another tree.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: The petioles are quite round, except for a curved indent along the top side.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: The leaves are about the same color on the top and bottom sides.

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: While the leaflets curve downwards slightly, the two sides are flat towards the tip and somewhat v-shaped towards the petiole.

children.title: Rachis top side
children.comments: The top side of the rachis has a ridge in the center.

children.title: Rachis top side
children.comments: The bottom side of the rachis is round.

children.title: Leaf tip
children.comments: The tip of all Chamaedorea end in two leaflets. The leaflets on this species are thick, ridged and leathery.

children.title: Fruit
children.comments: The females readily fruit and form dense clusters of ornamental orange to red berries (1/3" to 1/2" roundish ellipsoid on green stems).
children.location: Gary and Lynette Wood's South Coast Palms

children.title: Female inflorescense
children.comments: They can still fruit even with no pollination, but those should not be viable.

children.title: Inflorescense
children.comments: The inflorescences grow from the bottom of the crownshaft, but are usually very tall like this one.

children.title: Inflorescense
children.comments: There are seeds at the top of this tall trunked form; whereas the ones at the top of the green trunk are from another Chamaedorea behind it.

children.title: Male inflorescense
children.comments: The male flowers can continually release pollen for many months.

description: These were to the left of the previous picture. They have greener leaves. All of these have very white crownshafts.
title: Dypsis

children.title: decipiens
children.comments: Taken in 2006, this is a picture of one of the oldest of this species in California, definitely the most famous. (If you want to know the date any of the pictures on this site was taken, see the copyright notice‚ the copyright year will always indicate when the picture was taken.)

children.title: Profile
children.comments: Taken in 2006, this is a picture of one of the oldest of this species in California, definitely the most famous. (If you want to know the date any of the pictures on this site was taken, see the copyright notice‚ the copyright year will always indicate when the picture was taken.)

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This specimen has straight leaves and a light green crownshaft.
children.location: Dr. Marty and Cheri Darian's hilltop home

children.title: Blue-green
children.comments: It is a variable species. The one on the right has very curved blue-green leaves.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: These were to the left of the previous picture. They have greener leaves. All of these have very white crownshafts.

children.title: Blue form
children.comments: This one is labeled Dypsis sp. Blue decipiens. It does seem different with very straight leaves that twist unusually, and a very green crownshaft.
children.location: Jeff and Suchin Marcus’ Floribunda Palms and Exotics (www.floribundapalms.com)

children.title: Young profile 2004
children.comments: This one with two stems is green and very plumose, especially for such a young tree.

children.title: Growth 2010
children.comments: This is the same two-stemmed tree as in the previous picture, only six years later.

children.title: Young profile 2003
children.comments: The first in a series to show growth rate–this one started out with three stems, but by 2003 it only had two.

children.title: Young profile 2004
children.comments: The second in a series to show growth rate was taken one year later. This species tends to be moderately slow when young but gets to be fast when large.

children.title: Young profile 2007
children.comments: This picture was taken 4 months after the hard freeze in January of 2007. The Ravanea rivularis on the right got much more damage than the Dypsis. The brick-red in the crownshaft is because the leaf was cut off, so the base turned brownish as it died and before it fell off.

children.title: Growth 2010
children.comments: This picture was taken only three years after the previous picture. They really start to take off and grow fast as they get into developing a trunk.

children.title: Growth 2013
children.comments: Three and a half years after the previous picture. That looks like almost a foot a year.

children.title: Growth 2014
children.comments: The last pictures of this palm were taken a year later. The following year it died, a trunk with no head.

children.title: Super decipiens
children.comments: Labeled Dypsis sp.  'super decipiens', it has red new leaves.
children.location: Dr. Marty and Cheri Darian's hilltop home

children.title: Juvenile
children.comments: The leaves on young plants tend to be more flat, not as plumose-looking.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: This specimen has beautifully curved leaves.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: This specimen has rather straight leaves with only a slight curve at the tips.

children.title: Trunk bulge
children.comments: This is one of the oldest D. decipiens in California, and is starting to exhibit the bulge in the trunk.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: These regular D. decipiens have green leaves and very narrow rings in the trunks.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: The rings on slower growing types are tight without much color in the trunks.
children.location: Dr. Marty and Cheri Darian's hilltop home

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: The faster growing types have rings that are wide and some have white and/or gold for 1-3 feet below the crownshaft.

children.title: Regular crownshaft
children.comments: The crownshaft on this blue-green regular D. decipiens is narrow and totally covered with white powder.

children.title: Super crownshaft
children.comments: The crownshaft on this 'super decipiens' is wider than the top of the trunk and only partially covered with white powder.
children.location: Dr. Marty and Cheri Darian's hilltop home

children.title: Super crownshaft
children.comments: The crownshaft on this other 'super decipiens' is also wider than the top of the trunk and only partially covered with white powder.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: The petioles on this 'super decipiens' fit the normal description: very short (4-10") and can be sharp.

children.title: New leaf
children.comments: The main distinguishing characteristic of 'super decipiens' is the red leaf spear.

children.title: New leaf
children.comments: This tree was labeled D. decipiens (not super), but it has the red new rachis of a 'super decipiens'. It is the only D. decipiens in the Huntington Library, so the next picture, and all from there might be 'super decipiens'.

children.title: Leaf bases
children.comments: The edges of the leaf bases can have dark fiber.

children.title: Rachis bottom side
children.comments: On some, the rachis is paler and more yellow green than the leaves.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: Straight leaves with a slightly curved to very curved tip is common in cultivation.
children.location: Dr. Marty and Cheri Darian's hilltop home

children.title: Leaf upper side
children.comments: Their pinnate leaves are slightly to very plumose-looking.

children.title: Rachis upper side
children.comments: Here you can see the irregularity of the leaflet groupings and the concaved rachis upper side, that is unusually wide near the petiole and very narrow at the tip.
children.location: Dr. Marty and Cheri Darian's hilltop home

children.title: Blue-green leaf
children.comments: This blue-green color is common in habitat more than in cultivation.
children.location: Jeff and Suchin Marcus’ Floribunda Palms and Exotics (www.floribundapalms.com)

children.title: Super leaf
children.comments: Leaves on 'super decipiens' tend to be green with no blue tint.
children.location: Dr. Marty and Cheri Darian's hilltop home

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: These very curved blue-green leaves show how strongly V-shaped they are in cross-section view.

children.title: Dying leaf
children.comments: When the leaves are dying, like the crownshaft, they turn into appealing colors of gold, orange and red before turning brown and naturally falling off.

children.title: Leaflets
children.comments: Leaflets are grouped in clusters of 2-5, held at an angle (not parallel to the rachis as most leaflets are) and fanned out to give their plumose-look.

children.title: Leaflets
children.comments: The leaflets closest to the petioles are usually limp and much longer and narrower than the rest.

children.title: Illustration
children.comments: This illustration was published in 1945 under the name Chrysalidocarpus decipiens.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

title: Jubaeopsis
comments: The leaves sometimes have a twist along the rachis.
location: Gary and Lynette Wood's South Coast Palms

children.title: caffra
children.comments: Growth rate picks-up a little as they start to mature.

children.title: Profile 2005
children.comments: Older trees look very nice with their leaf bases trimmed down low. This is the same tree as in the next picture, only photographed 10 years earlier.

children.title: Profile 2015
children.comments: This is the same tree as shown in the previous picture, only photographed 10 years later. Growth rate is not terribly slow after they have a few feet of bare trunk.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This species needs a lot of water. It does not grow as well with regular or less water, which will show in brown tipped leaves.

children.title: Overgrown
children.comments: This picture is a good example of the formless mound this species becomes when allowed to have too many trunks. It was taken right after the big freeze in 2007 when it went down to the lower 20s at this location, and shows only a little damage to the frond tips.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: The trunks on the right show the spiraling vertical rows of leaf bases. Each trunk on this species has five rows.

children.title: In Hawaii
children.comments: Jubaeopsis grow best in Mediterranean climates with medium to low humidity and cool nights, but they also like plenty of water and good draining soil. This one in Honolulu looks quite happy.

children.title: Juvenile 2002
children.comments: This is the same palm taken three years earlier than the one pictured in the next photo, and ten years earlier than the one after that.

children.title: Juvenile 2005
children.comments: This is the same palm taken three years later than the one pictured in the previous photo, and seven years before the one in the next photo. Growth rate is very slow when they are young.

children.title: Adelescent 2012
children.comments: This is the same palm taken seven years later than the one pictured in the previous photo. Growth rate picks-up a little after developing their maximum widths, which can take decades.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The upright leaves, especially on the forms that are so upright that they are like a shaving brush, makes them easier to walk under even when relatively small. This tree is not getting as much sun as they prefer.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The leaves are v-shaped and stiff when young.

children.title: Trunks
children.comments: The fiber from the leaf bases wraps around the trunk and shows between the rows of leaf bases.
children.location: Gary and Lynette Wood's South Coast Palms

children.title: Trimmed trunk
children.comments: Older trees look very nice with their leaf bases trimmed down low.

children.title: Overgrown
children.comments: Some trees do not develop many stems, but most in California keep producing suckers even at a ripe old age.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: Petiole colors vary greatly, from green, yellow, gold, and bright orange to dark orange.

children.title: Leaf bases
children.comments: The leaf bases have long fibers along the edges, but the petioles are bare.
children.location: Gary and Lynette Wood's South Coast Palms

children.title: Leaf underside
children.comments: The leaves are straight and then arching usually from around the mid-point, although where the arching starts varies.

children.title: Leaf topside
children.comments: The light to medium green leaflets are regularly spaced and close together.

children.title: Leaf twist
children.comments: The leaves sometimes have a twist along the rachis.
children.location: Gary and Lynette Wood's South Coast Palms

children.title: Rachis
children.comments: The rachis (the part of the leaf stem that holds the leaflets) is usually the same color as the petiole though slightly to much more green.

children.title: Rachis topside
children.comments: The topside of the rachis does not have as much color as the bottom side (shown from the same tree in the next picture). There is a pale raised ridge along the center fold on the top side of each leaflet.

children.title: Rachis bottom side
children.comments: The bottom side of the rachis is much more colorful and wider than the top side.

children.title: Brackets
children.comments: The inflorescences (3-4' long, much shorter than the leaves) emerge encased in two brackets. The long upper one turns woody and persists.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: The inflorescences are branched once (to one order).

children.title: Fruit
children.comments: The fruit look much like Jubaea's fruit only smaller (1" in diameter).

title: Laccospadix
comments: Laccospadix are lovely shade loving small palms that can tolerate below freezing, but are rarely seen in landscapes.

children.title: australasica, multi-stem
children.comments: New leaves can be burgundy red, bright red, copper colored, muted bronze or regular green.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: Although they will be happy with more sun or shade, the filtered shade of this lath house is perfect for this species.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: The petioles are longer when grown in more shade.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: In Hawaii, or other climates where they get plenty of humidity and cloud cover, they can be grown in the sun. The leaflets are more straight and the petioles shorter when grown in the sun.
children.location: Jeff and Suchin Marcus’ Floribunda Palms and Exotics (www.floribundapalms.com)

children.title: Profile
children.comments: Multi-stemmed Laccospadix do not get as tall and are slower than the single form.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: Laccospadix are lovely shade loving small palms that can tolerate below freezing, but are rarely seen in landscapes.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The leaves are ascending so the crown rarely forms more than a hemisphere.

children.title: Trunks
children.comments: They have dark green ringed stems on the upper bare parts and tan on the old part of the trunks.

children.title: Trunks
children.comments: The stems look much wider than reality when covered with old leaf bases.

children.title: Trunks
children.comments: They have dark green ringed stems on the upper bare parts and tan on the old part of the trunks.

children.title: Young trunks
children.comments: Seeds from multi-stemmed plants will bear seedlings that become multi-stemmed, unless the seeds were cross pollinated.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: The unarmed petioles are quite concave on the top sides and convex on the under sides.

children.title: New red leaf
children.comments: The new leaves have more red coloring when they first open.

children.title: New red leaf
children.comments: Different palms have variously colored new leaves.

children.title: Leaf upper side
children.comments: The new leaf is often a muted pale brick red. When grown in the shade the leaflets are more arching.

children.title: Reins
children.comments: When they first open they have reins (lorae) connecting the leaflet tips, but that falls away by the time the leaf is fully opened.

children.title: Leaf upper side
children.comments: This one still has some of the reins between the leaflet tips on the left.

children.title: Leaf underside
children.comments: The leaves have evenly spaced leaflets that are on one plane on each side.

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: The almost straight, only slightly arching leaves have leaflets that are somewhat V-shaped along the rachis, especially closer to the petiole.

children.title: Leaflets
children.comments: The leaves do not end with two symmetrical leaflets at the tip.

children.title: Rachis top side
children.comments: The top side of the rachis is angled and comes to a point between the two rows of leaflets.

children.title: Rachis underside
children.comments: The underside of the rachis has short brown tomentum.

children.title: Rows of fibers
children.comments: They have rows of scattered dark fibers on the underside of the leaflets.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: Their non-branching inflorescences form three to four-foot solitary spikes and are different from the other species in their subtribe because the flowers grow out of indented areas of the stem (rachilla).

children.title: Seeds
children.comments: Laccospadix is different from the other genera in that the flowers grow out of indented areas of the inflorescence stem (rachilla).

children.title: australasica, single
children.comments: This picture was taken 12 years prior to the previous picture. It shows the moderate rate of growth for this form when it is large enough to have a naturally clean trunk.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: The single form tends to grow taller and faster than the kind with multiple trunks.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: Seeds from a single trunked specimen will produces single trunked seedlings.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This is the tallest Laccospadix this author has seen in California.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This picture was taken 12 years prior to the previous picture. It shows the moderate rate of growth for this form when it is large enough to have a naturally clean trunk.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: The leaves are ascending so the crown rarely forms more than a hemisphere.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This specimen has very upright leaves.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: In Hawaii, or other climates where they get plenty of humidity and cloud cover, they can be grown in the sun. The leaflets are more straight and the petioles shorter when grown in the sun.
children.location: Jeff and Suchin Marcus’ Floribunda Palms and Exotics (www.floribundapalms.com)

children.title: Crown
children.comments: This tree was growing in dense shade, so the petioles are much longer and the leaflets are droopier.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: Although they will be happy with more sun or shade, the filtered shade of this lath house is perfect for this species.

children.title: Leaf bases
children.comments: The leaf bases fall off easier and flair out wider when the trunk is tall.

children.title: Leaf bases
children.comments: The leaf bases are retained longer and grow more upwards when the trunk is short.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: They have dark green ringed stems on the upper bare parts and grayish tan on the old part of the trunks.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: In Hawaii, it is hard to tell the true color of the trunk because the humidity encourages growth on the trunk.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: The newest part of the stems are covered with leaf bases and their thin splits or fibers that detach from the leaf base edges and wrap around the trunk. There are small ligules around the emergent spear.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: The unarmed petioles are quite concave on the top sides and convex on the under sides.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: New leaves can be burgundy red, bright red, copper colored, muted bronze or regular green.
children.location: Jeff and Suchin Marcus’ Floribunda Palms and Exotics (www.floribundapalms.com)

children.title: Tip of leaf
children.comments: For more pictures of leaves, see the multi-stemmed form since the leaves are basically the same, but variable in both forms.

children.title: Leaflet underside
children.comments: They have rows of scattered dark fibers on the underside of the leaflets.

children.title: Rachis top side
children.comments: As is the case on all palms with pinnate leaves with pointed tips, the folds at the rachis point up with the open folded part pointed down (^).

children.title: Inflorescences
children.comments: The numerous inflorescences are not branched and form three to four-foot solitary spikes.

title: Phoenix
comments: The Phoenex roebelenii x reclinata on the left is next to several P. roebelenii on the right, a huge P. reclinata x canariensis behind them in the center and P. canariensis on the far right in the rear.

children.title: reclinata x roebelenii
children.comments: These at UCLA are among the few labeled as Phoenix reclinata x roebelenii, meaning that P. reclinata was the mother plant. Most in California are labeled as Phoenix roebelenii x reclinata, either because the P. roebelenii was the mother or because they did not know which was the mother.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Profile
children.comments: Phoenix roebelenii x reclinata and Phoenix reclinata x roebelenii are very similar and both variable enough to lump the two together in this discussion, which is limited to the multiple stemmed forms. Usually crosses resemble the mother more than the male, but these do not seem to follow set rules.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Profile
children.comments: These at UCLA are among the few labeled as Phoenix reclinata x roebelenii, meaning that P. reclinata was the mother plant. Most in California are labeled as Phoenix roebelenii x reclinata, either because the P. roebelenii was the mother or because they did not know which was the mother.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Profile
children.comments: Phoenix easily hybridize, partly because they are diocious (each plant is male or female). P. reclinata and the single form of P. roebelenii have been cultivated for a long time, so the crosses are not uncommon.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: It is an elegant palm that adapts well to an array of different growing conditions like this one in the desert. The cross is much faster and easier to grow than either of its parents.

children.title: Never trimmed
children.comments: When left to its own devises, untrimmed, it becomes a big mound of dead leaves topped with green leaves. Interesting but not appealing.

children.title: Needs trim
children.comments: This old 35' tall grouping of several multi-stem crosses has not been trimmed for years but still looks stunning since it was well groomed when younger.

children.title: Trimmed
children.comments: They look best when trimmed to 5-7 stems of varying height. This one was unharmed by 21F in 2007. Others in Northern California have survived 18F after being heavily damaged.

children.title: Resembles reclinata
children.comments: This specimen definitely resembles its P. reclinata parent more than most of these crosses. The leaflets are stiff and while not as plumose as most P. reclinata, it is distinctly more so than most crosses.

children.title: Near reclinata
children.comments: This one had three new stems removed and successfully transplanted, but then it stopped growing any newer stems. P. reclinata is on the left, with its stiffer and more plumose leaves. These two Phoenix were about the same size when they were planted ten years earlier. The cross is much faster.

children.title: Near roebelenii
children.comments: The Phoenix roebelenii x reclinata on the left is next to several P. roebelenii on the right and a huge P. reclinata x canariensis behind them. The leaves on most of these P. roebelenii x reclinata crosses are much more like the P. roebelenii than like the leaves of P. reclinata (see previous picture).

children.title: Bare trunks
children.comments: The trunks on this species are quite variable, depending on which species the trunk takes after. This one looks like the trunk of its mother, a P. reclinata, thick with rough edges and wide pointed knobs and vertical slits between the knobs.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Adventitious roots
children.comments: This one looks older. It also shows the P. reclinata characteristics. These have adventitious roots, which extend higher up the trunks than normal, presumably where they have been damaged.

children.title: Trunks with leaf bases
children.comments: This cross can tenaciously hold on to its unsplit leaf bases with their fibers wrapping around all the other leaf bases.

children.title: Trunks like roebelenii
children.comments: This one's trunks take after its mother: P. roebelenii 'reasoneri', the multi-stemmed form of P. roebelenii. The old leaf bases retain their color much longer, the bare trunks do not have such very rough edges and there are no vertical cracks like on P. reclinata.

children.title: New stems
children.comments: This one is fifteen to twenty years old and has had the new stems cut off or dug out and successfully transplanted many times. It is still constantly producing new stems.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: The fibrous growth from the sides of the lower part of the leaf bases starts out as sheet and then separates into fibers with time.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: The fibers growing from the sides of the leaf bases look like thick threads lower on the trunk. The petioles can have a mild covering of tomentum.

children.title: Spines
children.comments: One of the easy ways to identify Phoenix is that they all have petioles with leaflets modified into stiff, sharp spines (acanthophylls) that always stick out on multiple planes.

children.title: Long leaves
children.comments: These very long leaves exhibit a small amount of the characteristic twist along the rachis that many Phoenix have.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: These leaves exhibit more of the characteristic twist along the rachis.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: The leaflets are regularly spaced and on one plane on each side near the tip, but turn more irregular and slightly plumose towards the petiole.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: The leaf length is quite variable. This one is fairly long.

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: The leafy part of this leaf is fairly short, but the petiole with its characteristic spines is taking a larger percentage of the leaf than on most.

children.title: Leaf like reclinata
children.comments: A close-up of the leaves of the above specimen that resembles its P. reclinata parent more than most of these crosses. The leaflets are stiff, wider and more closely spaced than most crosses.

children.title: Leaf curve
children.comments: This leaf is more typical of the cross, with its thin flexible leaflets that droop down in some areas. It looks more like its P. roebelenii parent.

children.title: Leaf tip
children.comments: The leaves end in one leaflet at the tip.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: Like on P. reclinata, the male inflorescence bracts can be green, yellow, orange or red-orange--very attractive.

children.title: Fruit
children.comments: The bracts on the female inflorescences are not colorful like on the males, but the inflorescences are much longer.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: roebelenii x reclinata, single
children.comments: Although limited to the single forms, Phoenix roebelenii x reclinata and Phoenix reclinata x roebelenii are very similar and both variable enough to lump the two together in this discussion. Usually crosses resemble the mother more than the male, but these do not seem to follow set rules.

children.title: Group planting 2012
children.comments: This is a group of three single stem P. reclinata x roebelenii on the left and one more by itself on the right.

children.title: Group planting 2006
children.comments: These are the same four as in the previous picture only six years earlier. At this stage, they are moderately fast growers, not very fast, but not slow.

children.title: Mature profile
children.comments: Although limited to the single forms, Phoenix roebelenii x reclinata and Phoenix reclinata x roebelenii are very similar and both variable enough to lump the two together in this discussion. Usually crosses resemble the mother more than the male, but these do not seem to follow set rules.

children.title: Mature profile
children.comments: Most of these crosses in California are labeled as Phoenix roebelenii x reclinata, either because the P. roebelenii was the mother or because the mother was unknown.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: The cross is much faster and easier to grow than either of its parents. It is an elegant palm that adapts well to an array of different growing conditions like this one in Northern California. It was heavily damaged in 2007 when it suffered through many hours per night for multiple nights in the high teens F, but it recovered well.

children.title: Beefy specimen
children.comments: The single form of this cross is usually taller and larger in all aspects than the multi-stem form.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: Most of these single crosses are naturally single stemmed because they take after the single-stemmed P. roebelenii parent.

children.title: Was multi-stem
children.comments: This picture was taken late in the day with the sun shining through the leaves, making them look temporarily yellow. The plant is a stem that was removed from a multi-stem form in the ground. It was cut apart from the group about 6 years earlier, but has never suckered.

children.title: 3 trunks
children.comments: These three single stemmed crosses have smoother bare trunks than on P. reclinata, but much larger than on P. roebelelinii.

children.title: Rough trunk
children.comments: This one's bare trunk is more like a P. reclinata with vertical cracks and rough edges.

children.title: Tall trunk
children.comments: Most palms of this cross retain their fiber wrapped leaf bases for many decades.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: One of the easy ways to identify Phoenix is that they all have petioles with leaflets modified into stiff, very sharp spines (acanthophylls) that always stick out on multiple planes.

children.title: Long leaves
children.comments: These crosses are variable. This one has very long, thin leaves.

children.title: Trimmed crown
children.comments: This one has been recently trimmed. Most of the the single form has leaves more like P. roebelenii with soft leaflets that do not have sharp tips (except the spines on the petioles).

children.title: Rachis top side
children.comments: The somewhat limp leaflets are regularly spaced and on one plane on each side near the tip, but turn more irregular and slightly plumose towards the petiole.

children.title: Rachis bottom side
children.comments: This is a very easy genus to identify. It is the only genus with pointed pinnate leaflets that fold upward where attached to the rachis (v-shaped, technically called induplicate).

children.title: Male inflorescence bracts
children.comments: Like on P. reclinata, the male inflorescence bracts can be green, yellow, orange or red-orange--very attractive.

children.title: Male inflorescence
children.comments: The male inflorescences are very short.

children.title: Male flowers
children.comments: Only the male flower release pollen when shaken.

children.title: Female inflorescences
children.comments: The bracts on the female inflorescences are not colorful like on the males, but the inflorescences are much longer.

title: Plectocomia
comments: This large rattan gives a strikingly tropical look to this small yard. The thick heavy stems cannot hold themselves upright, needing support by letting them climb into sturdy trees or structures.

children.title: himilayana
children.comments: The younger leaf bases can have unusually pretty coloring, yellow, green and white, along with yellow petioles fading into lime green rachises.

children.title: Searching for support
children.comments: This large rattan gives a strikingly tropical look to this small yard. The thick heavy stems cannot hold themselves upright, needing support by letting them climb into sturdy trees or structures.

children.title: Lower half in 2006
children.comments: Same as the previous picture, this is where it was planted, behind the royal palm. It is already growing multiple trunks from the ground.

children.title: Profile in 2002
children.comments: This picture of the same tree shown above (previous picture) was taken only four years earlier. The top leaves are included in this picture. It grew about three feet a year after this. That is very fast for a palm.

children.title: Profile in 2016
children.comments: This specimen is growing in a climate that occasionally goes down into the high teens (F) and regularly into the low 20sF.

children.title: Profile in 2010
children.comments: This is the same tree previously pictured, three years earlier. They are fast, but not as fast in this climate and at that age.

children.title: Seedling
children.comments: Seedlings and larger are hard to find, even in specialty nurseries.

children.title: Baby spines
children.comments: They have sharp spines at a young age.

children.title: Plectocomia hymalyana, vine
children.comments: The trunks can be single, or they branch to become multi-trunked.

children.title: Branching stem
children.comments: The trunks can grow sideways to find support, and branch anywhere along the trunk, as shown here, although the leaves were cut off that branch.

children.title: Yellow coloring
children.comments: The younger leaf bases can have unusually pretty coloring, yellow, green and white, along with yellow petioles fading into lime green rachises.

children.title: Leaf bases
children.comments: The stems are covered with green and light brown retained leaf bases that have brownish hairs and very ornamental needle-like spines arranged in tightly packed diagonal rings.

children.title: Leaf base spines
children.comments: An interesting characteristic of this genus is the way the spines are joined together in a solid strip–like a piece of plastic tape that is connected along its other edge to the leaf base.

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: Short (one-foot long) leaflets are usually irregularly arranged and spread on different planes like plumose leaves.

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: Although this one is curving downward, the leaves are normally stiff.

children.title: Leaf under side
children.comments: The leaflets are green on both sides, which is a distinguishing feature because the other species have grayish undersides.

children.title: Leaf margins
children.comments: Even the leaflets are minutely spiny along the margins. This is another distinguishing feature since the other species of Plectocomia do not have the spiny margins.

children.title: Leaf tips
children.comments: This is the only species of Plectocomia that has thread-like extensions on the tips of the leaflets.

children.title: Rachis
children.comments: The rachises are very thin for the size of the leaves (6 - 8' long).

children.title: Rachis spines
children.comments: The rachises have short, sharp spines in widely spaced clusters.

children.title: Petiole
children.comments: The petioles are short, one foot or less, and of course are armed with sharp spines that are arranged in groups.

children.title: Cirrus
children.comments: The rachis extends beyond the leaves to become the plant's cirrus, the whip-like extension, used for climbing and attaching the vine to its support. (Shown in the top half, along the left side of the photo.)

children.title: Cirrus
children.comments: The cirrus (spiny leafless extensions of the leaf stem) is normally three feet long. One cirrus is shown in the top right half of the photo, and more smaller cirri can be seen below and above that leaf towards the left half of the photo.

children.title: Cirrus spines
children.comments: The cirrus are usually thin and covered with widely spaced groups of spines.

children.title: Cirrus spines
children.comments: The spines on the cirri are stouter and more angled than on the rest of the plant. These spines, too, are connected at the base.

title: Pritchardia
comments: The tallest one is P. hillebrandii, and a very tall one at that.

children.title: hillebrandii
children.comments: This is one of the most striking specimens with blue leaves.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: If you want to make a garden look like it should be in Hawaii, Pritchardia will do the trick. They are very tropical looking, especially for a fan palm.

children.title: Tall specimen
children.comments: The one on the left was labeled Pritchardia hillebrandii. The tall thin trunk with a large round crown brings the tropics to mind.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: The best news is that they are easy to grow in Southern California.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Profile in 2003
children.comments: In 2003 this P. hillebrandii was small with only a few feet of trunk.

children.title: Profile in 2005
children.comments: Two years later shows rapid growth.

children.title: Profile in 2009
children.comments: In four more years the tree has continued to grow fast.

children.title: Profile in 2013
children.comments: Another four years shows that the growth rate has not slowed down. The average over the last 10 years is about a foot a year.

children.title: Profile in 2016
children.comments: Usually a palm's growth slows down when it gets tall or at all close to its maximum height, but after two and a half more years, this one is still shooting up there.

children.title: Pale leaves
children.comments: One of the identifying characteristics of this species is that it has a bit (or sometimes a lot) of glaucous on the top of the leaf blades.
children.location: Chip Lyle and Helen Arnold's Green Valley Garden

children.title: Protected specimen
children.comments: Being grown in a climate that regularly freezes every winter, sometimes down to the high teens F., this specimen is protected from too much sun with shade cloth, and from the cold with other protective cloth.

children.title: Young palm
children.comments: The leaves are not as round when young.

children.title: Tall specimen
children.comments: The tallest one is P. hillebrandii, and a very tall one at that.

children.title: Typical
children.comments: This is a typical P. hillebrandii for its size: with white tomentum on the petioles and leaflets lower fold edges, narrow trunk, and undulating, half round leaf blades.
children.location: Jeff and Suchin Marcus’ Floribunda Palms and Exotics (www.floribundapalms.com)

children.title: Very blue
children.comments: This is one of the most striking specimens with blue leaves.

children.title: Blue Moon
children.comments: This palm, called 'Blue Moon', is from the seed of a tree that has blue leaves, so hopefully it will develop more glaucous on the leaves as it matures, but because of the way genetics works, that cannot be guaranteed.
children.location: Jeff and Suchin Marcus’ Floribunda Palms and Exotics (www.floribundapalms.com)

children.title: Blue Dwarf
children.comments: Those with 'Blue' in the name, like this 'Blue Dwarf' were grown from seeds of a blue form. Seedlings from these blue forms do not necessarily turn blue, in fact few with this name do, but any blue form has more of a chance to turn blue when mature if grown in full sun.
children.location: Gary and Lynette Wood's South Coast Palms

children.title: Blue Dwarf seedling
children.comments: The dwarf forms of this species grow up to be shorter, with a narrower trunk and a more compact crown than the regular P. hillebrandii. They are also slower growing and can handle more cold, possibly down to 25F.

children.title: Tall trunk
children.comments: Although the experts say they will only grow to 25' tall, this trunk is well over 30' tall, but in cultivation there is always the chance that something was sold by the wrong name.

children.title: Bare trunk
children.comments: Once the trees are large, the leaf bases can easily be removed, or fall off on their own.

children.title: Leaf base fibers
children.comments: The leaf bases have only a little fiber along the edges, less than most other species.

children.title: White fuzz
children.comments: The leaf bases and petioles can have a thick coating of white fuzzy tomentum.

children.title: Tan fuzz
children.comments: The tomentum can be a tan or peach color on the leaf bases and petioles.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Green leaf bases
children.comments: Many have very little tomentum on the leaf bases and petioles, except for on the new leaves.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Long petioles
children.comments: The petioles are usually as long as the leaves, but can be longer when grown in some shade.

children.title: Short petioles
children.comments: The petioles can be shorter when grown in the full sun.

children.title: Petiole shape
children.comments: The leaf bases and petioles are U-shaped.

children.title: Crowns
children.comments: The handsome crowns on all forms of this species are full and spherical.

children.title: Canopy
children.comments: The crowns are especially attractive looking up at the canopy of leaves.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: This palm is growing near the coast and in the shade. It has much greener bottom sides of the leaves than most of this species.

children.title: Costa
children.comments: The white fuzz is more typical when near the coast.
children.location: Gary and Lynette Wood's South Coast Palms

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: The leaves form a half circle with the leaflets split 1/3 to 1/2 way down to the petiole.

children.title: Hastula
children.comments: They only have hastulas on the top side of the leaves.

children.title: Wavy leaf profile
children.comments: Some of them have very wavy leaf profiles and stiff leaf tips.

children.title: Flat leaf profile
children.comments: Some of them have somewhat flat leaf profiles and limp leaf tips.

children.title: Segment tips
children.comments: Each segment tip is split for a medium to short distance, and then can end with long thin dead fibers.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: Hermaphroditic monoecious (one tree can reproduce). The inflorescences are born between the leaves, are branched to three orders (branched twice) and can be solitary or with 2 to 4 together in each axil.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: The inflorescence is shorter than on many of the other species, usually no longer than the petioles when flowering, but can be longer when in fruit.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: The main inflorescence stems are covered with multiple long bracts.

title: Ravenea
comments: Composite of two pictures: palm from South Coast Plaza, Costa Mesa, put in a background picture of the Stevens' Ranch in Valley Center.

children.title: rivularis
children.comments: This picture was taken 10 years after the previous picture. It also shows a rate of growth of about one foot per year.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: The trunks are sometimes said to be white, but off-white or very pale tan would be more accurate, as you can see comparing these trunks to the white wall in the background (left).

children.title: Growth rate
children.comments: This picture was taken 5 years after the previous picture. It shows a rate of growth of about one foot per year.

children.title: Young profile
children.comments: 3 years later: They grow at a moderate rate from 3-foot seedling until about this age when they start growing more rapidly.

children.title: Growth rate
children.comments: This picture was taken 10 years after the previous picture. It also shows a rate of growth of about one foot per year.

children.title: Group
children.comments: This species makes a great mass planting, especially since it is inexpensive and easy to grow (if you give enough water, fertilizer and magnesium).

children.title: young profile
children.comments: A very adaptable species, it will grow well in sun or in shade where it is easier to keep deep green, but is not as fast.

children.title: Growth rate
children.comments: This picture was taken 9 years after the previous picture. This shows that it is not as fast in the shade as when grown in the sun.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: They can grow to be 90' tall in their native habitat. Since we do not know how long it took them to get up there, time will tell what the maximum height will be in California.

children.title: In desert
children.comments: They can handle dry air and high temperatures in the desert, if given enough water.

children.title: After freeze
children.comments: Still recovering two and a half years after the big freeze of 2007 when the temperatures went into the teens (F). To minimize the damage, the owner kept water dripping day and night during most of the cold season.

children.title: Tall specimen
children.location: Dr. Marty Darian's neighbor's front yard

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The leaves are self-cleaning (fall off after turning brown). This is an unusually full crown.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The leaves are green on this tree, so it must have been given Epson salt (magnesium sulfate). Without enough of it the leaves turn yellow, which is the most common problem with these palms.

children.title: Canopy
children.comments: The leaf bases are often covered with peachy white fuzzy tomentum. They do not form a crownshaft.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: On others the leaf base fuzz is more brown and paler towards, and on, the undersides of the petioles.

children.title: Leaf bases
children.comments: The edges of the leaf bases are rough with loose fibers hanging from the exposed areas. The actual green color of the leaf bases and petioles peaks through from under the tomentum.

children.title: Trunks
children.comments: The trunks are usually wide and columnar in shape (like the one the left), but can vary. Most will taper at the top and some will have slight bulges in the middle (like the one in the right foreground).

children.title: Leaf twist
children.comments: The leaves twist along their central stems (rachis), so that the tip is parallel to the trunk.
children.location: Jeff and Suchin Marcus’ Floribunda Palms and Exotics (www.floribundapalms.com)

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: The first half of the leaves are fairly straight, and then they curve gently after their twist and even more near the tips.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: They have evenly spaced thin, but straight, leaflets on one plane that are medium green, more bright or yellow-green than most palms.

children.title: Reins
children.comments: When they first open they have reins (lorae) connecting the leaflet tips, but that falls away by the time the leaf is fully opened.

children.title: Rachis bottom side
children.comments: The fuzzy tomentum continues from the leaf bases and petioles up the bottom side of the fairly flat or rounded (concave) rachis.

children.title: Rachis top side
children.comments: The rachis is keeled; the topside sticks up much higher than the part of the rachis where the leaflets are attached.

children.title: Rachis
children.comments: As the rachis gets closer to the stem, the raised center keel gets flatter and the flat part gets wider.

children.title: Rachis
children.comments: This cross section shows the unusual shape with a keeled part of the rachis being quite tall. This section was from near the tip, so the top of the keel is not flattened yet.

children.title: Leaflet bottom side
children.comments: They have rows of scattered fibers along the main veins on the underside of the leaflets.

children.title: Leaflet bottom side
children.comments: The bottom side of the leaflets have minute whitish scales along with the rows of larger fibers.

children.title: Flowers
children.comments: Each inflorescence has two bracts. The flowers are yellowish white.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: Female inflorescences tend to appear orangish-red from unpollenated small seeds. They need to be pollenated by a male tree to produce their round half-inch red seeds.

title: Rhapidophyllum
comments: This may be the tallest Rhapidophyllum in California, with trunks over five feet tall.

children.title: hystrix
children.comments: This must have been trimmed when young and then kept as a double.

children.title: Mature profile
children.comments: Like many other palms, Rhapidophyllum have shorter petioles and stiffer leaves when grown in full sun.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: California's tallest
children.comments: This may be the tallest Rhapidophyllum in California, with trunks over five feet tall.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This palm was not trimmed heavily when young, so now has many large stems.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This must have been trimmed when young and then kept as a double.

children.title: Single
children.comments: When grown in the shade and kept as a single, this species looks more tropical, elegant and graceful.

children.title: Trimmed group
children.comments: This group of different trees where all trimmed heavily when younger.

children.title: Untrimmed
children.comments: When left untrimmed, they turn into a multi-stemmed formless mound.

children.title: Legules
children.comments: Their long ligules tend to be curly.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: Their leaf-bases are densely covered with a coarse weave of fiber between the spines.

children.title: Trunk spines
children.comments: This species is commonly called the needle palm or the porcupine palm because of the very long spines on their trunks.

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: Their profiles are not flat, but more cupped.

children.title: Leaf topside
children.comments: The leaf blades are deeply, irregularly split.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: The leaf blades have whitish fuzz uniformly on the bottom side.

children.title: White bottom
children.comments: The same leaf as in the previous picture, when the fuzz reflects the light, it makes those areas appear white and those that are not catching the reflections look green.

children.title: Leaf tips
children.comments: They have multiple folds per segment. Each fold has its own little pointed or rounded end.

children.title: Leaf tips
children.comments: Some segments have as little as half of a fold to one and a half folds, others have eight or more folds, but most segments include about three or four folds.

children.title: Hastula
children.comments: The top side has a very small, almost inconspicuous hastula.

children.title: Under hastula
children.comments: The bottom side has no hastula. The end of each split has a raised pale bump, which is visible from both top and bottom sides of the leaf blade.

children.title: Split ends
children.comments: It looks as if the splits in the leaf blade were stopped with a drop of glue.

children.title: Petiole
children.comments: The petioles are unevenly covered with tomentum (pale fuzz) and are triangular in shape.

children.title: Flowers
children.comments: The inflorescences are the same length or shorter than the spines.

children.title: Flowers
children.comments: The inflorescences are usually branched once, but sometimes not at all.

title: Rhopalostylis
comments: The crownshafts are typically light green and very bulbous.

children.title: sapida
children.comments: They look good grown in groups.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This is a typical R. sapida

children.title: Group planting
children.comments: They look good grown in groups.

children.title: Mass planting
children.comments: This mass planting will be stunning when they get tall.

children.title: 3-in-1 hole
children.comments: Three plants in one-hole curve gently away from each other. Very nice.

children.title: Typical form
children.comments: This park had one of the oldest large groups in California, but most have died, presumably from being watered less for many years, even though their lawns look great. The Rhopalostylis on the left is R. cheesemanii, with its more spread-out and slightly curved leaves and leaflets, and its taller, narrower reddish crownshaft.

children.title: Faster form
children.comments: There are many different forms of this species. This one is growing faster than the ones previously pictured, evident by the widely spaced rings on the trunk.
children.location: Richard Josephson and Loretta Rao residence

children.title: Narrow form
children.comments: This form has a narrow, tall crownshaft, more upright leaves and narrower leaflets.

children.title: Profile in shade
children.comments: This one has a moderately bulbous crownshaft with slightly curved leaves that are less upright, but then it is in the shade near the coast.

children.title: Tall specimen
children.comments: This slow growing typical form was planted 45 years before this picture was taken.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: This is a typical crown with narrow, closely spaced leaflets, very ascending, no petioles and a bulbous crownshaft.

children.title: Unusual crown
children.comments: This one has wider leaflets than is typical, but still closely spaced so they look overlapping. The curved leaves that spread out and the only slightly bulbous reddish crownshaft makes it look like a R. baueri, but the extremely short petioles, small fruit and small rings on the trunk indicate R. sapida.

children.title: Crownshaft
children.comments: The crownshafts come in various shapes and sizes, so cannot be used as the determining identifier.

children.title: Bulbous crownshafts
children.comments: The crownshafts are typically light green and very bulbous.

children.title: White rachis
children.comments: This typical R. sapida has the bulbous crownshaft and white rachis.

children.title: Crownshaft
children.comments: The crownshaft on this one is longer and not very bulbous.

children.title: Young crownshaft
children.comments: It is common for them to not show their bulbous traits when young.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: Most R. sapida have no petioles, or very short ones.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: The trunks typically have very closely spaced rings from growing very slowly.

children.title: Green trunk
children.comments: The trunks are green between the rings, except on the lower part of old trunks.

children.title: Old trunk
children.comments: This older trunk, on the left, does not show much green.

children.title: Leaf upper side
children.comments: When they first open the leaves have reins (thin strips technically called lorae) connecting the leaflet tips, but that falls away by the time the leaf is fully opened.

children.title: Leaf under side
children.comments: The leaflets are typically so close together that you cannot see through between the leaflets, unless they are particularly thin.

children.title: Rachis upper side
children.comments: The top side of the rachis is usually green on older leaves and is angled with the center indented slightly and wider and concaved towards the stem.

children.title: Rachis under side
children.comments: The rachis can have a coating of white tomentum on some R. sapida, but not all.

children.title: Leaf tips
children.comments: The tips end in two leaves, but they are not symmetrical.

children.title: Species compared
children.comments: The palm on the left was purchased as R. sapida, on the right as R. 'Oceana', and in the center rear as R. baueri. R. sapida have more upright stiff leaves with tightly spaced stiff leaflets. This R. baueri is much faster. R. 'Oceana' is said to be a form of R. sapida, but is very different (see R. sapida 'Chatan Island' for more on that form).

children.title: Flowers
children.comments: All Rhopalostylis male flowers have 6 stamens, which distinguishes it from Hedyscepe with their 9-10 stamens.

children.title: Pink flowers
children.comments: The flowers on Rhopalostylis can be pink or white.

children.title: White flowers
children.comments: This one has white flowers.

children.title: Fruit
children.comments: R. sapida's elliptic-oblong fruit are usually around 1/4" in diameter. Their smaller, bright red fruits can be used to distinguished them from R. baueri (1/3 to 1/2" in diameter).

children.title: Inflorescences brackets
children.comments: The bracts that enclose the emerging inflorescences usually fall off quickly.

children.title: Illustration
children.comments: Rhopalostylis sapida was officially named in 1878. Some of these older illustrations were used to describe it. It was known as Areca sapida in 1845 when this was illustrated.
