children.title: Illustration
children.comments: This illustration was published in 1850 under the name Areca sapida.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Illustration
children.comments: This illustration was published in 1853 under the name Areca sapida.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: sapida 'Chatan Island'
children.comments: Labeled R. 'Oceana': Close-up of the densely white coating.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: R. sapida 'Chatan Island' look like a cross between R. sapida and R. baueri.

children.title: 2015 profile
children.comments: Labeled R. 'Oceana', which is another name for R. sapida 'Chatan Island': They tend to have more white fuzz on the petioles.

children.title: 2009 profile
children.comments: Labeled R. 'Oceana': This is the same tree as in the previous picture, five and a half years earlier. The rachis and leaf bases looked more white when younger.

children.title: Very white
children.comments: Labeled R. 'Oceana': These young palms look like they are covered in pure white on all parts but the leaflets.

children.title: Very white
children.comments: Labeled R. 'Oceana': Close-up of the densely white coating.

children.title: Species compared
children.comments: The palm on the right was purchased as a R. 'Oceana', on the left as a R. sapida, and in the center rear as a R. baueri. R. sapida have more upright stiff leaves with tightly spaced stiff leaflets. This R. baueri is much faster.

children.title: Species compared
children.comments: Left palm labeled R. 'Oceana': It has much longer petioles than the regular form of R. sapida (example shown on the right) or even the R. baueri in the center, which has reddish tomentum and spaced-out, not stiff leaflets.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: Labeled R. sapida 'Chatan Island': The wide rings on this palm are very unusual for a R. sapida. It means it is not slow growing.

children.title: Crownshaft
children.comments: Labeled R. sapida 'Chatan Island': The crownshaft shape is somewhat bulbous, which is in between R. sapida (very bulbous) and the typical R. baueri (more slender and tall).

children.title: Young crownshaft
children.comments: Labeled R. 'Oceana': The crownshafts are not as bulbous when young.

children.title: Short petioles
children.comments: Labeled R. sapida 'Chatan Island': This one has slightly longer petioles then the regular R. sapida.

children.title: Long petioles
children.comments: Labeled R. 'Oceana': This one definitely has longer petioles then the regular R. sapida.

children.title: Long petioles
children.comments: Labeled R. 'Oceana': This one has much longer petioles than the regular R. sapida, but then it is younger and growing in the shade.

children.title: Red petioles
children.comments: Labeled R. sapida 'Chatan Island', so it probably is, but at this stage it could also pass for a R. cheesemanii with its long reddish petioles and rachis, and very wide, not closely spaced and slightly lax leaflets.

children.title: Red rachis
children.comments: Labeled R. sapida 'Chatan Island' (same tree previously pictured): It also has the reddish fuzz on the new leaf spike and new leaflet edge and ridges.

children.title: White new spear
children.comments: Labeled R. 'Oceana': It is typical for this form to have an abundance of white tomentum on the new leaf spear and the petioles and rachis. This one also has it on the edges of the newer leaflets.

children.title: Leaf under sides
children.comments: Labeled R. 'Oceana': The leaves on this one look more like a regular R. sapida (straight, with closely spaced, stiff leaflets), except for more reddish again.

children.title: Leaf upper side
children.comments: Labeled R. 'Oceana': When they first open the leaves have reins (lorae) connecting the leaflet tips, but that falls away by the time the leaf is fully opened.

children.title: Rachis under side
children.comments: Labeled R. sapida 'Chatan Island': The rachis under side is curved.

children.title: Rachis upper side
children.comments: Labeled R. 'Oceana': The top side of the rachis is angled with the center indented slightly near the tip (pictured) and concaved towards the stem.

children.title: Fruit
children.comments: Labeled R. sapida 'Chatan Island': This form has larger fruits (more than 1/4' wide) than regular R. sapida, more like R. baueri's 1/3 to 1/2" wide fruits.

children.title: Rachis upper side
children.comments: Labeled R. sapida 'Chatan Island': The rachis upper side is grooved in the middle and smooth's into a concave curve towards the petiole.

children.title: Fruit
children.comments: Frost blight

children.title: repens
children.comments: This is one of the more unusual silverish colored Serenoa. Some have much more silver leaves, but those are rare.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This is an old plant with the typical light green leaves. This is the more commonly seen color for Serenoa.

children.title: Curved habit
children.comments: It is common to see the multiple stems curved away from each other like this.

children.title: Upright form
children.comments: It is unusual to see Serenoa so tall and upright.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This one has a pale bluish green color.

children.title: Juvenile
children.comments: This picturesque Serenoa is growing with Guadua angustifolia, a beautiful but frost sensitive bamboo.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: Unless a specimen is kept as a single trunk, it is difficult to view the crown because the various crowns are usually all bunched together like in the previous pictures.

children.title: Upright trunks
children.comments: The leaf-bases are retained with the bottom parts, and the rest of the trunk, covered with a dark brown woven fiber.

children.title: Creeping stems
children.comments: Most Serenoa in habitat have subterranean or creeping stems, like this one.

children.title: Ligules
children.comments: At the top of the stem the fibers form ligules, but these do not turn into shaggy hairs on the trunks

children.title: Petiole teeth
children.comments: The two-foot petioles are concaved on the top side and convexed on the bottom, and have numerous minute but sharp teeth.

children.title: Leaf topside
children.comments: The leaf blades form a complete circle, are deeply divided to more than three fourths, and are very stiff, feeling more like plastic than like leaves.

children.title: Leaf topside
children.comments: The top sides have raised ridges between the segment, from the end of the split to the petiole.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: Working on making this picture into a painting effect, Chris Stevens left the front leaf in photograph form to show all the leaf detail.

children.title: Leaf bottom profile
children.comments: The segments are on various planes, especially near the petiole and in the center of the leaf blade.

children.title: Hastula on top
children.comments: The topside hastula is brown and pointed.

children.title: Hastula on top
children.comments: The hastulas on the topside are quite variable.

children.title: Hastula on bottom
children.comments: The hastula on the bottom side has turned brown and brittle and most of it has broken off.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: On the bottom side, the leaves have raised ridges running down the center of each segment, from the tip to the hastula. Most of this hastula has broken off, which is common on the bottom side.

children.title: Bifid tips
children.comments: The segment tips are deeply bifid (have two tips for several inches).

children.title: Flowers
children.comments: This form has silvery leaves and petioles. In the bottom right corner, you can see where they have been trimming away the new stems to keep this palm more attractive.

children.title: Flowers
children.comments: This shows the more yellow green petioles compared with the bluish green leaves.

children.title: Immature fruit
children.comments: These petioles show slightly larger thorns near the trunk.

children.title: Male tree
children.comments: has some female flowers and produces fruit/seed

children.title: Female tree
children.comments: Green fruit

children.title: wagnerianus
children.comments: *although some botanists still accept this name, others lump it into T. fortunei

children.title: Profile
children.comments: *although some botanists still accept this name, others lump it into T. fortunei

title: Trithrinax
comments: Trithrinax schizophylla, with deeply split, pale green leaves, is in the foreground on the left, T. campestris, with icy blue-grey leaves is behind it and to the right, and T. acanthocoma, with large, flat, stiff dark green leaves, is in the center behind the others.

children.title: acanthocoma
children.comments: An old specimen.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This old specimen has a typical crown, but is unusual with its bare trunk showing at the base of the tree.

children.title: Younger profile
children.comments: This especially beautiful specimen has a nice round crown of flat stiff leaves with slightly glaucous bottom sides.

children.title: Old specimen
children.comments: This is a particularly tall specimen among those cultivated in California. It is about 30' tall. Because it is growing in the shade, it has more droopy leaves and longer petioles than if it were in the full sun.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Group
children.comments: This species have variable leaf color; dark blue-green is quite popular.

children.title: Comparison
children.comments: The T. brasiliensis on the right are much shorter than the three tall flowering T. acanthocoma in the center.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: This is a typical crown with flat stiff leaves. Note that these form a complete circle, which is a variable trait.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: This genus is easy to distinguish by its spiny trunk.
children.location: UCLA's Mildred E Mathias Botanical Garden

children.title: Trunk spines
children.comments: The spines on their trunks attach to a loose net of coarse fiber.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: The spines can be covered with tomentum at the top of the trunk. These spines shown lower down are 7-9" long.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: The petioles are unarmed and may or may not have thick pale fuzz on them.

children.title: Stiff leaves
children.comments: This specimen has typical stiff leaves that form 3/4th of a circle and have entire or only shortly bifid leaflet tips. Seen from the side, it looks totally flat.

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: The petioles are unarmed and may or may not have pale fuzz on them.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: This one has fairly stiff leaves that form a little more than a half circle and does not show any glaucous except near the hastula.

children.title: Floppy leaves
children.comments: At first sight, this might look like a T. brasiliensis with its floppy leaves that are deeply split, especially some of the tips. But that is a variable characteristic in both species. This tree has the large leaves with sharp tips, the wide trunk with very long spikes and the medium fast growth rate typical of its species, T. acanthocoma.

children.title: Hastula on top side
children.comments: The top side of this species' leaf usually has a small to large point in the center of its prominent hastula.

children.title: Hastula on underside
children.comments: Most palmate palms do not have significant hastulas on the bottom side. They are relatively large on T. acanthocoma, and they have the characteristic curve and point in the center.

children.title: Fruit
children.comments: This species produces great quantities of seeds that sprout easily beneath the trees.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: The inflorescence has golden yellow branches and flowers with another spathe at each major branch.

children.title: Fruit
children.comments: The fruits on this species can be larger than on T. brasiliensis.
children.location: John Cressey and Greg Haines Residence

children.title: Spent inflorescence
children.comments: It is easier to see the structure of the inflorescence and count the number of branches on them when they are spent and dried-out.

children.title: Description illustration
children.comments: This palm illustration was published in 1878, in the same publication and issue that it was described in and officially named. So this must be the illustration from that description. It shows a leaf blade that is not as deeply split between the segments as on T. brasiliensis.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Old illustration
children.comments: This palm illustration was published in 1882, four years after it was described. The segment tips are entire or split for only a short distance, not noticeable enough to show in this drawing.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: biflabellata
children.comments: Even though it looks very different, it is sometimes lumped in with T. schizophylla.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: Although this specimen is the oldest one known in California, it is still short. They are very slow growing and never get very tall.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: Even though it looks very different, it is sometimes lumped in with T. schizophylla.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: Although the small leaves are sometimes light grayish-green, they are more often yellowish, or light green.

children.title: Deeply split
children.comments: The leaves have relaxed or sometimes even dangling leaflets that are deeply split. This plant is surely a T. biflabellata, but must have been labeled as T. schizophylla when the two were merged.

children.title: Less split
children.comments: Some plants are not as deeply split as others, especially when young.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: This one has deep splits between the leaflets.

children.title: Young profile
children.comments: This one is a seedling from the plant previously pictured. They are monoecious, so one palm can reproduce.

children.title: Roots
children.comments: When being repotted, it was noticed that there were two plants, each with multiple stems in the one pot. This one was separated from the one in the previous picture.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: They have the smallest, thinnest trunks in this genus.

children.title: Trunks bifurcate
children.comments: They tend to bifurcate from below the soil line, and then can do this many times again as time goes on.

children.title: Spines
children.comments: The spines around each leaf base are still 3-6" long.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: They are on narrow petioles, one to three feet long by less than a half inch wide.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: Each leaflet has deeply split bifid tips on this plant. But that characteristic is variable.

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: This is the same plant as in the previous picture, and the leaflets do not look like they have deeply split tips.

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: The name biflabellata means divided leaf blades since the leaves are sometimes divided almost to the hastula between the two longest center segments. But this one does not have that characteristic. It may be too young, or just a variable trait.

children.title: Young leaves
children.comments: This one is much younger than the previous one pictured, but has deeper splits.

children.title: Hastula top side
children.comments: The hastulas are small but prominent.

children.title: Tips not sharp
children.comments: One of the easiest ways to distinguish this from T. schizophylla is if the leaflet tips are not sharp at all then they are T. biflabellata.

children.title: brasiliensis
children.comments: Unlike the others, this palm illustration (published in 1871) shows this species with only slightly split or entire leaflet tips. It does show the characteristic floppy leaves and narrow trunk. Because T. acanthocoma was lumped into and therefore called T. brasiliensis for some decades, these illustrations are the only pictures that definitely represent T. brasiliensis (T. brasiliensis var. brasiliensis).
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Crown
children.comments: This is the only Trithrinax that we could find in Southern California that really appears to be a T. brasiliensis when that is distinguished as a different species or subspecies than T. acanthocoma. Note the more slender trunk and droopier leaves with deeply split bifid tips.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This specimen has the characteristic floppy leaves with drooping tips and glaucous undersides, and the narrow trunk of a T. brasiliensis, but the spines are longer and leaflet tips less bifid than expected on this species.

children.title: Group
children.comments: The three palms in the center-left are labeled T. brasiliensis. They are much shorter than the T. acanthocoma further back on the far right and far left.

children.title: Profile illustrated
children.comments: Unlike the others, this palm illustration (published in 1871) shows this species with only slightly split or entire leaflet tips. It does show the characteristic floppy leaves and narrow trunk. Because T. acanthocoma was lumped into and therefore called T. brasiliensis for some decades, these illustrations are the only pictures that definitely represent T. brasiliensis (T. brasiliensis var. brasiliensis).
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: The trunks on T. brasiliensis are the most reliable distinguishing trait. They are narrower, shorter and slower than on T. acanthocoma.

children.title: Trunk spines
children.comments: The label gives scale to show that T. brasiliensis has a much narrower and shorter trunk, with shorter spines than T. acanthocoma.

children.title: Comparison
children.comments: The trunks on the T. brasiliensis (the four in the center and right) are smaller than on the two T. acanthocoma (trunks only) on the left. On the left note that the fruit is smaller and turning black when fully ripe.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: Relatively short spines emerging out of a coarse net of fibers is typical of this species.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: This one is labeled T. brasiliensis, but has the long spines of a T. acanthocoma. Here you can see the extended petioles from growing in the shade.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: A trait of T. brasiliensis is soft, not sharp tips (which this specimen has), and glaucous leaf bottom sides and sometimes on the top sides.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: This one is even more glaucous, but is very stiff.

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: Besides the droopiness of the soft, thin leaflets, the leaves are very flat.

children.title: Leaflet tips
children.comments: A distinguishing trait of T. brasiliensis is soft, not sharp tips (which this specimen has), and the leaflet tips should be deeply bifid.

children.title: Leaflet tips
children.comments: The leaflet tips should be soft, not sharp from hard tips, which this tree has, meaning that these are either variable traits, or that this specimen was labeled this when all T. acanthocoma also went by the name T. brasiliensis.

children.title: Hastula
children.comments: They have the same pointed hastulas as the rest of the species in this genus.

children.title: Profile illustration
children.comments: This palm illustration was published in 1847. It shows T. brasiliensis with a slender trunk and at about 15' tall, near its usual maximum height.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Leaf illustration
children.comments: This palm illustration was published in 1847, ten years after it was described. It shows the deep split in the leaf blade, between the segments, which helps distinguish it from T. acanthocoma.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: Inflorescenes illustration
children.comments: This palm illustration was published in 1850. It shows the deeply split segments typical of this species in habitat. Only these illustrations are definitely T. brasiliensis.
children.copyright: Missouri Botanical Garden, downloaded from www.plantillustrations.org

children.title: campestris
children.comments: This species looks best when trimmed to one or three stems, and when the dead leaves are removed to reveal the interesting trunk.

children.title: Tall double 2004
children.comments: This is the tallest of this species known in California. It was about 25 feet tall then.

children.title: Fallen trunk 2007
children.comments: Sometime in the three years after the previous picture, the tallest trunk fell over. The top leaves just reach to the tree trunk behind it.

children.title: Tall double 2010
children.comments: Another three years later, the fallen trunk has grown horizontally to pass the tree trunk that was behind it.

children.title: Tall double 2013
children.comments: Three more years, and the head of the fallen trunk is trying to grow vertically and starting to lift up. The palm on the right is a Butia odorata x Jubaea chilensis.

children.title: Tall double 2015
children.comments: In yet another two years the head of the fallen trunk is now growing more vertically and the short one from the first picture is no longer short.

children.title: Roots
children.comments: This genus is known to grow roots from injured parts of the trunk. It is hard to tell if there are some new roots growing from the trunk near the soil, among the leaf bases and petioles.

children.title: Single 2006
children.comments: This specimen shows all the dead flower stems between the leaves. Since they are multi-stemmed, this one must have had the new pups removed to keep it as a single stem.

children.title: Trimmed 2010
children.comments: Four years since the previous picture, it was trimmed to reveal the long needles on the trunk.

children.title: Untrimmed multi-stem
children.comments: This older untrimmed specimen just looks like a big mound of leaves with no shape or form.

children.title: Very silver
children.comments: This picture, taken late in the day when shaded by the trees behind it, shows how silver some specimens can be.

children.title: Yellowish
children.comments: This one has more yellowish color in the leaves.

children.title: Silver
children.comments: This silver specimen has been trimmed to keep the size manageable.

children.title: Young profile
children.comments: The more stems allowed to remain on the plant, the slower the plant grows. This one is at least 25 years old.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The crown on a single stemmed plant will form a nice sphere.

children.title: Petticoat
children.comments: The dead leaf bases are retained, forming a very sharp petticoat.

children.title: Spines
children.comments: Covered with very ornamental netting that ends in rows of sharp, long spines, this is a typical trunk for its size.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: On this old trunk, the spines are broken or cut off, revealing more of the netting.

children.title: Bare trunk
children.comments: On very old specimens, the older parts of the trunk can become bare.

children.title: New pups
children.comments: Even old trunks can continue putting out new stems, but not as many as on younger plants.

children.title: Transplanting
children.comments: When preparing to divide the stems for transplanting, this grower makes trenches and cuts in the stem over many months, to give the plant plenty of time to grow new roots. Doing it all at once should work fine on this genus, but it is safer this way.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: Many have long needles at the top of the stem.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: On some the spines are shorter and the netting can be seen more. The petioles are short, 1/2 to 2 feet long.

children.title: Petiole cross section
children.comments: The top side of the petioles are flat near the leaf and slightly curved (concaved) when near the leaf base. The bottom side is very curved (convexed), so the cross section almost forms a triangle.

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: The leaves are deeply split between the segments, except the center two are often split far less.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: The leaves can form from a half, to a full circle or somewhat teardrop shaped circle, or diamond or wedge shaped. It is variable. This one is from a young plant, so does not have as many leaves as it will when older.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: The leaf blades are very tough, thick and stiff, like plastic leaves, so they are difficult to bend into a curve, but will fold if given enough force. This is the only Trithrinax with such rigid leaves, so touching the leaves (not the tips) and gently trying to curve them is the best way to identify T. campestris.

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: While some of these palms have fairly flat leaves, most have some or a lot of curve like a costapalmate leaf: the tips curve down, side leaflets go up, and the bottom leaflets veer downwards.

children.title: Hastula top side
children.comments: The hastula on the top side of the leaf is quite prominent and often pointed in the center and curved on the edges.

children.title: Hastula bottom side
children.comments: The bottom of the leaves also have a hastula, weaker than on top, and die and can break off on older leaves.

children.title: Sharp tips
children.comments: The leaflets, on mature older specimens, are generally over 1" wide (to almost 2"), much wider than T. schizophylla or T. biflabellata. The tips are bifid, sometimes very shallow like this one.

children.title: Bifid tips
children.comments: The length that the bifid tips are split varies greatly. Some are much deeper than this, but generally less split than T. schizophylla.

children.title: Straight tips
children.comments: Each bifid tip ends in its own exceedingly sharp and rigid spike. Since the leaflets are also very rigid, these tips are very dangerous.

children.title: Tip curves
children.comments: This curve at each bifid tip is usually only seen on two species of Trithrinax, T. campestris and T. acanthocoma, but not on all of them.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: The inflorescences emerge from between the leaves, and grow to be relatively short. They are branched twice (to 3rd order) and the lower first branches each have their own bracts.

children.title: schizophylla
children.comments: A few months later, it was trimmed to reveal the stems. They look much better this way. Also, one of the stems was removed, and more are being prepared to be cut away and put in pots.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: T. schizophylla are rare in California. Many labeled this in public gardens and nurseries are mislabeled. This one has the traits of a true T. schizophylla.

children.title: Profile 2010
children.comments: They are slow growing, especially when young. This one (in the foreground, on the left) was in the ground for 8 years when this picture was taken. It is much greener than the silvery T. campestris to the right of it.

children.title: Profile 2015
children.comments: Five years after the previous picture, it is a small mound of multiple stems. This greyish light to medium green is their typical color, but they can be more grey or more yellow green, like the leaves on the left side on this plant.

children.title: Trimmed
children.comments: A few months later, it was trimmed to reveal the stems. They look much better this way. Also, one of the stems was removed, and more are being prepared to be cut away and put in pots.

children.title: Preparing for division
children.comments: When preparing to divide the stems for transplanting, this grower makes trenches or cuts in the stem over many months, to give the plant plenty of time to grow new roots. Doing it all at once should work fine on this genus, but it is safer this way.

children.title: Recently divided
children.comments: This is the stem that was, about 6 months earlier, cut away from the plant previously pictured. The new leaves are dwarfed, but growing steadily, and it is growing roots out the bottom of the pot already. The leaves will get larger next year.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: This is one of the only true T. schizophylla in a public garden in California.

children.title: Leaves
children.comments: Same as the previous picture: it has the typical T. schizophylla characteristics, thin leaflets that are deeply split and thin multiple trunks.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: This one has much larger leaves than the previous one.

children.title: Spines
children.comments: The spines on the trunks are persistent, and much longer than on any other Trithrinax, up to 18" long on some large specimens.

children.title: Stems
children.comments: The trunks are much thinner than all other Trithrinax, except T. biflabellata.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: Their petioles are very thin and short, only one to two feet long by three fourths of an inch wide.

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: One of the ways to identify this species is by examining their leaves. They are very deeply divided (around 80%, only T. biflabelatta is as deep or deeper).

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: Their 19-30 thin pointed segments (on full grown plants) are green to silvery gray, and less than an inch wide.

children.title: Leaf top side
children.comments: Their leaves are variable in shape and color. The younger trees, like this one was from, have leaves with less segments and often not as full round as in the previous picture, even though these are from the same plant.

children.title: Leaf bottom side
children.comments: One of the easiest ways to identify this species is by its narrow leaflets that are stiff but not thick and ridged like T. campestris, and not as thin and pliable as T. biflabelatta.

children.title: Leaf tips
children.comments: Another way to identify this species is by its leaflet tips that are pointed and sharp but break with pressure, and die back on the older leaves. They do not poke nearly as badly as the ones on T. campestris, with their very ridged leaves that end in large sturdy spikes. The tips on T. schizophylla are more sharp and sturdy than on T. biflabelatta, which has basically harmless points.

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: The leaf profile is not flat like on T. acanthocoma.

children.title: Hastula top side
children.comments: The top side hastulas are pronounced.

children.title: Hastula bottom side
children.comments: They also have a hastula on the underside, pronounced, but smaller than on the top side, and it turns brown and falls off when the leaf is older, but still quite green.

children.title: Hastula bottom side
children.comments: The pale-green or silvery coloring comes from the various amounts of tomentum on the leaves.

children.title: Bifid tips
children.comments: Another way to identify this species is by its leaflet splits. They are divided into deeply bifid tips (1/8 to 1/2 divided, it can vary greatly).

children.title: Bifid tips
children.comments: This leaf, on the same tree as previously pictured, is more deeply divided.

children.title: Flower
children.comments: The flowers are whitish, but the stems are yellow, so it gives a creamy look over all.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: The inflorescence is very short, and only branched once (to 2nd order).

title: Washingtonia
comments: The easiest way to distinguish the three forms is comparing their tall, cleaned trunks. W. filifera is the fat trunked palm in the foreground, on the right, and W. robusta are all the tall skinny trunked palms on the left and in the background. W. x 'filibusta's trunk (the highest in the picture) is in the foreground, in between the other two.

children.title: filifera
children.comments: Washingtonia filifera, native to California, Arizona and Baja California, is the only palm native to California and the whole Western United States.

children.title: Comparing species
children.comments: The easiest way to distinguish the three forms is comparing their tall, cleaned trunks. W. filifera is the fat trunked palm in the foreground, on the right, and W. robusta are all the tall skinny trunked palms on the left and in the background. W. x 'filibusta's trunk (the highest in the picture) is in the foreground, in between the other two.

children.title: Mature palms
children.comments: Washingtonia filifera, native to California, Arizona and Baja California, is the only palm native to California and the whole Western United States.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: An unusually tall specimen with its petticoat removed by fire.

children.title: In habitat
children.comments: You can see how huge these trees are only when there is a person to show scale.

children.title: In habitat
children.comments: The lower portions of some of these trunks were cleansed by fire many years ago. Edith Bergstrom on the trail to Fern Canyon.

children.title: Petticoat
children.comments: Unlike W. robusta, W. filifera do not lose their leaves at the top of the tree when they grow very tall.

children.title: In a group
children.comments: W. filifera retain their dead leaves. The bare portions were most likely caused by fire many years ago.

children.title: In habitat
children.comments: In habitat these palms tend to grow only in groups because they only live where there is unusually abundant water.

children.title: In habitat
children.comments: In Palm Canyon the Washingtonia follow the stream. Otherwise, they only grow away from the stream in the flat areas and on the hillsides where there are springs to moisten the soil.

children.title: Curved trunk
children.comments: There are several leaning and curved trunks in the picnic area of Palm Canyon in Indian Canyons.

children.title: Curved trunk
children.comments: Hikers give scale to these massive giants.

children.title: After fire
children.comments: The palms in the foreground have lost their petticoat in a fire.
children.location: Thousand Palms Oasis, Coachella Valley Preserve

children.title: Crown
children.comments: W. filifera forms a nice round crown of leaves when the dead leaves are removed.

children.title: Petticoats
children.comments: These modest ladies have their trunks totally covered from tip to toe.

children.title: Petticoats
children.comments: A group of petticoated W. filifera can form an impenetrable wall.

children.title: Petticoat
children.comments: The typical petticoat of untrimmed and unburnt W. filifera flares out on the ground.
children.location: Thousand Palms Oasis, Coachella Valley Preserve

children.title: Trunks
children.comments: The lower portions of trunks were cleansed by fire many years ago; the shorter trees still have their full natural petticoats.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: A rare view of the center of a trunk.
children.location: Thousand Palms Oasis, Coachella Valley Preserve

children.title: Trimmed leaf bases
children.comments: A rare W. filifera in habitat with its leaves manually cut off.

children.title: Trimmed leaf bases
children.comments: This is what trimmed W. filifera usually look like in cultivation.

children.title: Adventitious roots
children.comments: Not all W. filifera have adventitious roots like these.

children.title: Adventitious roots
children.comments: Edith Bergstrom gives scale to six-foot adventitious roots.

children.title: Leaf bases
children.comments: The trunk is covered with a fibrous matt, which is mostly obscured by the split leaf bases.
children.location: Thousand Palms Oasis, Coachella Valley Preserve

children.title: Heart
children.comments: Although not common, W. filifera sometimes have brown coloring at the base of the petiole.
children.scene: habitat; miles from other palms in the town

children.title: Legules
children.comments: The top of the trunk has paper-like ligules.

children.title: Petiole thorns
children.location: Thousand Palms Oasis, Coachella Valley Preserve

children.title: Petiole thorns
children.comments: The thorns are sometimes surrounded by this whitish fiber. The newer petioles can also have this slight white mealybug coating.
children.location: Thousand Palms Oasis, Coachella Valley Preserve

children.title: Canopy
children.comments: Charred petioles and trunk with new leaves since the fire.

children.title: Leaf underside
children.comments: Palmate leaves form a complete circle.

children.title: Variegated leaf
children.location: Thousand Palms Oasis, Coachella Valley Preserve

children.title: Variegated leaf
children.location: Thousand Palms Oasis, Coachella Valley Preserve

children.title: Filament
children.comments: W. filifera were named after the abundance of filament on very young trees.

children.title: Filament
children.comments: The filament on young W. filifera are much more abundant than on W. robusta.

children.title: After recent fire
children.comments: In habitat on a hillside that had a wildfire about a year before these pictures.

children.title: After recent fire
children.comments: The palms along Willis trail were in a recent fire, which burnt away the naturally persistent petticoats.

children.title: After recent fire
children.comments: The black charred outer layer, left on the trunks from the fire, will wear away with time, leaving a normal brown trunk.

children.title: After recent fire
children.comments: The white crystals on top of the soil appear to be from an abundance of water repeatedly evaporating from these areas.

children.title: Canopy
children.comments: Washingtonia filifera are especially beautiful after being cleansed by fire.

children.title: Growing in water
children.comments: Palm Springs area has many small springs on the hillsides that are covered in indigenous palms (hence the name). This spring (pictured) runs down the hill making a muddy path that the palms love. It is one of many such springs along Willis trail.

children.title: Growing in water
children.comments: W. filifera seem happy to grow with their feet dangling in the water or embedded in the boggy soil of stream banks.

children.title: Growing in water
children.comments: Quite a number of W. filifera are found in shallow water in habitat.
children.location: Thousand Palms Oasis, Coachella Valley Preserve

children.title: Growing in water
children.comments: Many of these trees have their toes in the water.

children.title: In habitat
children.comments: Where these palms are on hills, in habitat, there are often fault cracks with water seeping out of the ground.

children.title: Long after fire
children.comments: The dark areas of soil is where a spring is causing those areas to be continuously wet.

children.title: Owl
children.comments: Many people prefer to remove the dead leaves when near the house since the dry leaves can catch fire easily and help it to spread rapidly. Many others keep the petticoats saying that beneficial critters such as this owl like to nest in them.

children.title: Owl
children.comments: A family of owls, in one nest, will eat 5000 to 20,000 rodents, such as rats, mice, voles and gophers, per year.

children.title: Various species
children.comments: W. x filibusta is the tallest palm pictured in the center-right foreground; it was much faster growing than the other two. W. filifera are the fat trunked palms in the right and left foreground, and W. robusta are all the tall skinny trunked palms on the left and in the background.

children.title: robusta
children.comments: Even though they come from Mexico, W. robusta are much more the icon for California than the native W. filifera.
children.state: California, then turned into mixed-media art by Chris Stevens in 2015

children.title: Group
children.comments: When grown together in a tight group, the individual trees lean out, away from each other.

children.title: Group
children.comments: These are very typical examples of this species, with spherical and compact crowns, stiff leaves, and tall thin trunks that flare wider at the bottom.

children.title: Petticoat
children.comments: The reason most W. robusta petticoats have individual dead leaves showing (like in the bottom of this petticoat) is due to rapid growth. This one looks like they cut off the water and it still grows well, just not rapidly. Once it slows down, the leaves bunch up and do not show the individual leaf blades.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: W. robusta are the skinny trunked palms that have lost their dead leaves on the upper part of the tree when it is quite tall. The W. filifera have wider trunks, but these are obscured in this picture by their persistent petticoats that do not show the individual dead leaves as much as the others. Since these two are growing side-by-side, there are probably several W. x 'filibusta' among the younger Washingtonia pictured.

children.title: Cleaning habit
children.comments: Unlike W. filifera, W. robusta lose their leaf bases naturally, but only above 30 to 60 feet up the trunk.

children.title: Curved trunks
children.comments: The taller and older the palms are, the more likely they are to lean and/or curve.

children.title: Leaning habit
children.comments: The two pairs of Washingtonia in the background each show the two species next to each other. They are much easier to distinguish with most of the skirts removed. The tall ones with a fuller, more compact crown and no leaves on the top part of the narrower trunk are W. robusta, and the not as tall ones, with bare trunks at the bottom of a thicker trunk and a small petticoat at the top are W. filifera.

children.title: Curved trunk
children.comments: This species sometimes curves and twists naturally, creating artistic landscapes. But if you try to do this by planting one at a slant, it will make an unnatural looking abrupt angle and then grow straight up.

children.title: Comparison
children.comments: Compare the two species: The two tall ones with fuller, more compact, brighter (color not shininess) green crowns and narrower trunks are W. robusta, and the shorter one, with a thicker trunk and sparse but more open crown of dull (as in muted, not lack of shininess) green leaves, is W. filifera.

children.title: Various species
children.comments: W. x 'filibusta' is the tallest palm pictured because it was much faster growing than the other two. W. filifera are the fat trunked palms in the foreground, on the right and on the left, and W. robusta are all the tall skinny trunked palms on the left and in the background.

children.title: 2003 comparison
children.comments: The large tree in the center is W. filifera. To its right is the slightly taller W. x 'filibusta'. Below the W. filifera are two newly planted 5 gallon palms: W. robusta on the left (behind the weeds) and on the right is W. species unknown (either W. x 'filibusta' or w. robusta). These are the same four Washingtonia shown in the following pictures in Valley Center.

children.title: 2005 comparison
children.comments: Two years after the previous picture, the two larger palms (W. filifera on the left and W. x 'filibusta' on the right) have both grown about the same amount, but the two newly planted ones (W. robusta and W. sp. unknown) are now shooting up.

children.title: 2008 comparison
children.comments: Three years later, the W. x 'filibusta' on the right is definitely taller than the W. filifera on the left, plus the W. robusta, in front of the above two tall trees, looks like it is trying to catch up to the W. filifera. The other group of three Washingtonia in the background, on the right, is also W. species unknown (either W. robusta or W. x 'filibusta').

children.title: 2010 comparison
children.comments: Two more years later, and the W. x 'filibusta' on the right is towering above the W. filifera on the left, plus the W. robusta, in front of the above two, looks like it is almost catching up to the W. filifera.

children.title: 2015 comparison
children.comments: W. x 'filibusta' is the trimmed one in the background, on the left. It is by far the tallest and fastest growing. W. filifera is in the middle and W. robusta is the other tall one on the right. It is the same height as W. filifera, but looks smaller because it is behind it.

children.title: Juvenile
children.comments: Juveniles have stiffer leaves than when the same tree is tall.

children.title: Cultivated crown
children.comments: Most cultivated W. robusta have nice round crowns.

children.title: Natural crown
children.comments: The crowns are not as round when they do not get much water.

children.title: Crowns compared
children.comments: The front center palm is W. robusta. It has the smallest, most compact crown of stiff leaves. Behind it and on the left is W. filifera with a more open crown of larger droopy leaves. The tallest is W. x 'filibusta', which, being a cross of the two, has characteristics between them.

children.title: Petticoats compared
children.comments: Janaka Stevens relaxes while his wife takes pictures, with W. filifera on the right and behind him (note their smooth, shaggy petticoats) and W. robusta on the left, where you can more readily distinguish each dead leaf.

children.title: Trunks compared
children.comments: Some of these had the leaves cut off, and others had the leaf bases removed to expose the clean trunk. When this species has adventitious roots, they are normally small like those visible in the lower left corner.

children.title: Trunk flare
children.comments: Width at the ground level is quite variable, but they all tend to be wider at the base, and then taper within the bottom 10 - 20' to be quite narrow after that. The tree in the background shows this well.

children.title: Leaf bases
children.comments: Fiber, that looks like woven burlap, can be seen between the deeply split leaf bases.

children.title: Green heart
children.comments: Petiole bottom and top of live leaf base has various amounts of gold, orange and brown streaking up from the leaf base, especially along the center.

children.title: Brown heart
children.comments: This one, compared with the previous picture, has much more of the typical brown on the live leaf bases and bottom of the petioles.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: Tomentum is a variable trait. This tree has petioles with tomentum along the edges and on some of the teeth. Note the golden line along the edge of curved thorns on the petioles.

children.title: Leaf underside
children.comments: Most W. robusta have stiff leaves that are not deeply split.

children.title: Leaf underside
children.comments: The stiffness and depth of split are variable traits. This tree is older and is subjected to a lot of wind. That helps it have more deeply split leaf blades with dangling segments that are themselves also deeply split.

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: The leaf blade profile is not flat; it tends to undulate with the lowest points at the center and near the petioles.

children.title: Juvenile leaf top
children.comments: W. robusta do not normally have as much fiber when young as on W. filifera juveniles.

children.title: Leaflet tips
children.comments: The segment tips near the center of the leaf blade are not usually split very much, but those near the petioles normally are.

children.title: Costa
children.comments: They tend to have a patch of beige tomentum on a yellow background around the costa (top of the petiole when it extends into the leaf blade).

children.title: Hastula
children.comments: The hastula is usually pointed, and is quite variable in length.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: The stalks of the inflorescences are longer than the leaves.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: They have numerous small cream-colored flowers.

children.title: Ripe fruit
children.comments: When ripe, each inflorescence holds a great number of small, black fruits, which readily sprout on their own over a long distance from the mother tree.

children.title: x 'filibusta'
children.comments: This is the 2015 view in a set of nine pictures showing the rate of growth in the three types of Washingtonia. The tallest tree (W. x 'filibusta', with its dead leaves removed by the electric company) is definitely the fastest at this stage. W. filifera (just to the left and behind the others) is the slowest.

children.title: Comparing species
children.comments: The easiest way to distinguish the three forms is comparing their tall, cleaned trunks. W. filifera is the fat trunked palm in the foreground, on the right, and W. robusta are all the tall skinny trunked palms on the left and in the background. W. x 'filibusta's trunk (the highest in the picture) is in the foreground, in between the other two.

children.title: 2006 profile
children.comments: Six years before the previous picture, showing speed of growth. W. x 'filibusta' is the tallest palm pictured--much faster growing than the other two until they get tall, then the W. robusta will start catching up. Notice the W. x 'filibusta' is more red-brown than the W. robusta.

children.title: 2001 comparison
children.comments: The large tree on the left is W. filifera. To its right is the slightly taller W. x 'filibusta'. These are the two tallest Washingtonia shown in the following pictures in Valley Center.

children.title: 2003 comparison
children.comments: The large tree in the center is W. filifera. To its right is the slightly taller W. x 'filibusta'. Below the W. filifera are two newly planted 5 gallon palms: W. robusta on the left (behind the weeds) and on the right is W. species unknown (either W. x 'filibusta' or w. robusta). These are the same four Washingtonia shown in the following pictures in Valley Center.

children.title: 2005 comparison
children.comments: Two years after the previous picture, the two larger palms (W. filifera on the left and W. x 'filibusta' on the right) have both grown about the same amount, but the two newly planted ones (W. robusta and W. sp. unknown) are now shooting up.

children.title: 2007 comparison
children.comments: Two more years, since the previous picture, and the W. x 'filibusta' on the right is growing much faster than the W. filifera on the left.

children.title: 2008 comparison
children.comments: Another year later, and the W. x 'filibusta' on the right is definitely taller than the W. filifera on the left, plus the W. robusta, in front of the above two tall trees, looks like it is trying to catch up to the W. filifera. The other group of three Washingtonia in the background, on the right, is also W. species unknown (either W. robusta or W. x 'filibusta').

children.title: 2010 comparison
children.comments: Two more years later, and the W. x 'filibusta' on the right is towering above the W. filifera on the left, plus the W. robusta, in front of the above two, looks like it is almost catching up to the W. filifera.

children.title: 2012 comparison
children.comments: Another two years later, and the W. robusta, in front of the tallest two, looks like it has caught up to the W. filifera. The other group of three Washingtonia in the background, on the right, also W. species unknown (either W. robusta or W. x 'filibusta') is also growing rapidly.

children.title: 2013 comparison
children.comments: After being overly trimmed by the electric company, because it is 35' away from the power lines. They said the dead leaves could blow upward and into the lines in a strong wind.

children.title: 2014 comparison
children.comments: Here the W. species unknown (center of tallest clump) is starting to grow faster than the W. robusta on its left. The W. filifera is now obscured by the taller palms that were planted as 5 gallon seedlings in 2003.

children.title: 2015 comparison
children.comments: This is the 2015 view in a set of nine pictures showing the rate of growth in the three types of Washingtonia. The tallest tree (W. x 'filibusta', with its dead leaves removed by the electric company) is definitely the fastest at this stage. W. filifera (just to the left and behind the others) is the slowest.

children.title: Profile
children.comments: A second W. x 'filibusta' at the same property in Valley Center is much more like W. filifera. It is also not nearly as fast growing.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The cross has shorter petioles, making a less open crown that has more green descending leaves than the typical W. filifera, but it is more open than most W. robusta.

children.title: Crown
children.comments: The second W. x ‘filibusta’s crown is much more like W. filifera than the one in the previous picture.

children.title: Canopy
children.comments: The leaves and crown are variable within each species, so the crosses are even more variable.

children.title: Canopies compared
children.comments: This W. x 'filibusta', on the left (same as the previous pictures in Valley Center), seems to take after W. robusta more than its other parent, W. filifera, on the right.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: The tree in previous pictures has brown areas at the base of the petioles.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: The first tree, again, viewed from across the field. It also has plenty of tomentum (fuzz) on the petioles.

children.title: Heart
children.comments: Unlike W. robusta, this second tree has virtually no brown at the base of the petioles (like many W. filifera) and has just a little tomentum (fuzz).

children.title: Trunk with petticoat
children.comments: The huge base makes this look like a W. filifera, but the distinctly individual dead leaves in the skirt shows its W. robusta parentage. Compare it with the W. filifera in the background on the right (or in the next picture) where only a few distinct leaves are visible.

children.title: Mature trunk
children.comments: Same tree as in previous picture after being trimmed the close resemblance to W. robusta is apparent in the narrow trunk.

children.title: Adventitious roots
children.comments: Another way to tell that this tree takes after its W. robusta parent is the flare at the base of the trunk. W. x 'filibusta' do not normally do that.

children.title: Leaf bases
children.comments: The split leaf bases have a woven fibrous mat showing through from behind and along the edges.

children.title: Trunk base
children.comments: This tree takes after its W. filifera parent; the trunk does not taper with a flare at the base. It maintains the same width and then slowly narrows.

children.title: Trunk
children.comments: Same tree as in the previous picture—the gradual narrowing is apparent.

children.title: Petticoat
children.comments: Same tree as in the previous picture‚--the petticoat looks more like a grass skirt than individual dead leaves.

children.title: Petioles
children.comments: The tall trimmed W. robusta-like tree viewed from below and close to the tree.

children.title: Petiole teeth
children.comments: The teeth are smaller than on most W. robusta.

children.title: Leaves
children.comments: The leaves are larger, with more deeply split, limp leaflets than W. robusta or the other W. x 'filibusta' on this property.

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: The leaves are extremely variable within each species, so are even more variable in the cross.

children.title: Leaves
children.comments: The one that takes after W. robusta has tighter leaves and shorter petioles than the other W. x 'filibusta' on this property.

children.title: Leaf underside
children.comments: The older leaves, on the same tree as the previous picture, seem to have more limp leaflets and longer petioles.

children.title: Leaf profile
children.comments: The profiles of the different leaves have various degrees of undulation; they are not flat.

children.title: Leaf upperside
children.comments: This is the tree that resembles W. robusta more than its other parent.

children.title: Leaf upperside
children.comments: This cross resembles W. filifera more than its other parent.

children.title: Costa
children.comments: There is a yellow area with a patch of tomentum around the costa on some, but not all crosses.

children.title: Petiole
children.comments: The petioles also have patches of tomentum (heavier towards the leaf blade), on some, but not all crosses.

children.title: Hastula
children.comments: The hastula is v-shaped.

children.title: Hastula
children.comments: The profile view shows how uneven the hastula (the part sticking up) is, especially on older leaves.

children.title: leaflet split
children.comments: Here is an example of a newer leaf that is not yet deeply split on the leaflets in the center (or tip) of the leaf blade.

children.title: leaflet split
children.comments: The leaflets are deeply split especially the outer leaflets near the petiole.

children.title: leaflet split
children.comments: The trees that resemble their W. filifera parents have more deeply split leaflets.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: The emergent inflorescence is longer than the leaves on this tree. That trait is variable.

children.title: Inflorescence
children.comments: The dead inflorescence stocks protrude out of the petticoat. The setting sun light gives a reddish cast near the top.
